r 20, 2014
												Bioshock 2 is an interesting beast: when it first came out, it was largely panned as being a rehash of the first game, and not a "proper" sequel. Yet, in retrospect having played Infinite, Bioshock 2 seems to be the one which will age most gracefully, and it has aged nicely thus far.Bioshock 2 is a First-Person Shooter in the vein of the original Bioshock, where you take on the role of a Big Daddy in the underwater city of Rapture. Where the original Bioshock explores the themes of Libertarianism, Bioshock 2 deals with Communism, perhaps not quite as strongly. Combat has been vastly improved by allowing access to both plasmids and guns simultaneously (which was used in Bioshock Infinite), while still retaining the full allotment of interesting weaponry. Additionally, trap versions of basically every form of plasmid are available for use in a series of "protect the Little Sister" sequences spread throughout the game.Bioshock 2 also handles the moral choice system much more eloquently than the first game, with some actual balance to the choices that need to be made - arguably the most successfully that I've found in any game.Ultimately, the game absolutely is more Bioshock, and it perhaps took place a tad too close to the original which is why it had as hard a time it did at release. Additionally, there's multiplayer achievements, but I don't expect that there's any real multiplayer activity at this pont, so...buyer beware on that aspect.All in all, it's a great time. and I highly recommend it. Also, I'd recommend picking up Minerva's Den: It's an excellent DLC which distills the formula to its core and is an all around enjoyable experience.

0, 2014
												BioShock unquestionably changed the world of first person shooters by setting a new bar for storytelling in video games. With an epic story that pitted sanity versus insanity, gamers played Jack, a plane crash survivor who stumbled upon the underwater city of Rapture. Your goal was not just freedom but also to bring down billionaire industrialist Andrew Ryan whose utopia dissolved into a freakish world of hellish experiments gone wild.It was a surreal experience that pitted the gamer against an army of the strange, the wrong and totally chaotic. Unlike those first person shooters set on alien planets, the future or on the battle field, BioShock was set in 1958 which only enhanced the gameplay experience in this alternate reality through the creepy music and settings. Of course, the stylised graphics and music made this even more plausible. Add in elements from the survivor genre to top it off and BioShock successfully created a worldwide hit.And here we are again, 3 years later and the underwater city of Rapture still breathes but a huge twist has been thrown into the story, thanks to the gamer now playing a Big Daddy. For the uninitiated, Big Daddy's were the huge golem like creatures from the original game who protected the Little Sisters. However, unlike the other Big Daddy's from the previous title, your avatar has free will and let's just say that if anyone or anything gets in your way, the repercussions will be deadly.Before starting your BioShock 2 experience, the viewer is treated to a very interesting cinematic that introduces you to the world of this bizarre universe. Although it begins in 1958 and without spoiling the story too much, you are separated from your Little Sister and you awake ten years later. When you finally do get control of your character, it's all a mystery as to who or what you are. However, just like the original, the story slowly comes together, piece by piece. If you want to get even more in-depth, diaries are littered throughout the gaming environment to enhance the story.As you wake within the Adonis Luxury Resort of Rapture City, you learn that this area was also used for genetic enhancements and so your journey begins of discovery and retribution. One of the main themes in the game is that girls are being kidnapped from islands around Rapture city in order to become Little Sisters for these twisted experiments. For this unnamed Big Daddy, you eventually have contact with Eleanor Lamb, the Little Sister you were once linked with. Unfortunately for her, her mother Sofia Lamb refuses to abide by your wishes and was the person responsible for your vile imprisonment. Needless to say, there are plenty of your in-your-face moments to the story of BioShock.To compliment the story and those wow moments is the amazing level design, especially the underwater areas. The game itself is a first person shooter, however it has elements of RPG and the survival genre to stir things up. Unreal Technology powers the gaming interface as you tackle the denizens of Rapture City from those gone mad on ADAM, the slicers and your gender twisted sisters which all produce a memorable and decent gaming experience.In terms of completion, BioShock 2 takes around 14-15 hours, give or take and has three alternate endings available to the player. For replay value, as the gameplay is so sturdy and the storyline so compelling, most gamers can easily get another play out of the game and go down another path to get that different ending. We've only completed BioShock 2 as a "good" Big Daddy, so we're eager to check out some of the other paths available for our character. Speaking of Big Daddy! The control system of BioShock 2 has been well mapped and gamers of all different levels of experience will easily be able to control all facets of Big Daddy, even its deadly drill connected to its arm. If you have played the original, it does take a small amount of time getting use to this monstrous creature as opposed to a human but best of all, Big Daddy has access to some powerful heavy artillery such as Gatling guns and the like. When it comes to combat, the player has options of melee, weapons or genetic powers. With that said, the game is quite violent at times, especially when you're using your drill to disembowel your enemies. Big Daddy's were quite powerful in the original game and to make things fair to your enemies, they have received a slight power make-over. As you fight Splicer's or Big Sisters, it's great how they use the environment to their advantage such as cover and even health stations to replenish their health. Depending on your difficulty setting, the AI can be quite vicious towards the player and does make the game that extra bit more challenging. I played on a medium setting and did get my butt handed to me on more than one occasion but that's where upgrades, new weapons and new powers come into play.When battling enemies, it's quite surreal seeing the enemies fight as they do mimic real-world players quite well. But sometimes you need to fight fire with fire and our favourite Big Daddy has a few of his own powers such as Telekinesis 3 which allows for almost Star Wars based powers as you throw items and even smaller critters around the screen. BioShock 2 supports dual weapons which is generally unleashed when your fighting one of the myriad of bosses but what I like about BioShock 2 is using the environment to your advantage such as flammable pipes, BOOM, or unleashing deadly electrical EVE into the water to dispose your enemies.In relation to bosses, they are quite powerful and if you do manage to die which you will, you will reappear in a rejuvenation chamber to fight again. My favourite battles in BioShock 2 are definitely the Big Sisters that pierce the sound barrier upon their arrival who have the force of a Big Daddy but unfortunately for you, the abilities of the Spider Slicers "speed" which will be frustratingly challenging at times but well worth the victory. Of course, not all BioShock is about fighting and you need to hack doors for entry, vending machines for supplies and even bots to fight at your side. ADAM is used to upgrade your powers and abilities and the player uses Little Sisters to harvest this powerful genetic material. Of course to get a Little Sister, the player must first dispatch the Big Daddy that is protecting them. Once a Little Sister is yours, you can them use them to draw ADAM from corpses. This brings another strategy into the game through the use turrets and traps because once the Little Sisters start to harvest, other enemies are alerted, so you need to defend them quite well. As EVE played a huge role in the previous game which allowed you to use your powers, this also needs to be collected and replenished in BioShock 2. Fortunately, there are plenty of EVE hypos littered through the environments and some foods that can replenish it.When it comes to graphics, BioShock 2 is oozing with eye candy and looks amazing on high definition. The level design is brilliant that is complimented with some great lighting and special effects, especially the water. The characters are well animated and contain some great texture details, making it easy to be absorbed into the story of this "nameless" Big Daddy. The soundtrack is fitting and has a retro 1940's feel to it as is the voice acting, especially from our villain who is as mad as a hatter.From the very first moments, BioShock 2 holds an iron grip over you throughout the entire experience as you're given a violent tour of the legacy of Andrew Ryan's Rapture and the repercussions of his troubled dream. Some may say, it's the same as the previous game but I digress, it's a whole new chapter to this amazing underwater universe and if you don't believe me - buy it and you'll find out.

AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Bioshock 2 Original Release: 2010 Genre Tags: FPS; Atmospheric; Action; Story Rich My Overall Grade: A Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 8-20 hours Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseursREVIEWBioshock 2 returns the player to the vividly atmospheric world of Rapture and reintroduces all of the positive qualities that were prevalent in the first installment of this franchise. It is very, very similar to the first; so expect it to play like a refined continuation rather than an entirely new game. But it does offer a more intimate perspective on the underwater dystopia, as the player will take on the role of a unique Big Daddy this time around and will be much more connected to the city. Most of the features are extremely similar to their counterparts in the original game; however there was definitely fine-tuning applied to some aspects. Perhaps most prominently, the combat and overall gameplay is significantly more exciting this time around. Overall, it is a great game that was mostly successful in living up to the high standard set by the first game.Now, it is essentially a direct sequel. Having played both games, I would suggest that you attempt to play the first one before this, if you can afford the time and money. Although, it isn’t entirely necessary and you could opt to read a synopsis rather than play through the entire first game. But I would suggest you at least do that to get a little background information. Doing so will provide you the opportunity to fully enjoy the subtle nuances throughout the game.As for the specifics, Bioshock 2 is a fundamentally well-crafted game for all the same reasons the original was. At the forefront, there is once again an exceptionally intriguing atmosphere and a wondrous gameworld design. The city of Rapture continues to fascinate. Throughout your adventure, you will probably notice that all of the subtle niceties and ancillary details add up to create a very immersive and pleasurable experience. I personally feel the ambiance of the gameworld is best quality of this game and holds true to the brand.The multidirectional storytelling that was expertly executed in the first game also returns in this sequel. The main storyline will unfold as you progress through the campaign, but you also can learn a great deal about the backstory and lore if you explore and if you seek out the collectibles. A lot is left up to the player to determine how much he/she wants to learn about the lore. The narrative elements are mostly well written and enticing; and the foundation of it all is the superbly idiosyncratic NPCs. It all comes together quite nicely. All of that said, the narrative elements as a whole may feel a little less interesting in Bioshock 2 than they were in the first— perhaps due to the unavoidable loss of novelty of core concepts that is intrinsic to all sequels.As for the actual gameplay, it is significantly more exciting in Bioshock 2 than in the original.  There were nice refinements to the combat system, and the fact you now can maul people with the patented Big Daddy Drill is an added bonus. But also the actual fight sequences are better designed, and the layout of the combat zones provides more opportunities for creativity and hazard-kills. And new gameplay systems like the harvesting of ADAM from dead splicers really brings the high-action combat element of the game to the forefront of the overall experience much more than in the first installment.There is also a multiplayer mode and although it has the potential to be quite fun, it suffers from a low population and not-so-friendly community of regulars. If you have the patience to deal with the wait times and inevitable toxic matches, you will occasionally find yourself in some games that can be pretty enjoyable. But I wouldn’t count on the multiplayer adding too much value to the game; the focus is definitely on the campaign.In summary, I would say that Bioshock 2 is a very good game, although perhaps not quite as masterful as the original. It is strongly tied to its predecessor, and so it would probably be best to play both if you want to get the full experience. But either way, most established FPS/RPG gamers should be fully able to enjoy this game, especially fans of strong narratives and intriguing atmospheres.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

r 23, 2014
												Bioshock 2 was set up almost from the onset to be a colossal failure. It was to follow one of the most critically acclaimed games of all time, by a different developer, with the inclusion of a seemingly tacked on multiplayer mode to a series that had absolutely no need for one. It had every possibility to be a disaster, which makes it almost shocking that it arrived in a state that was not only comparable to the original game, but improved and expanded on it as well in ways that would be hard to go back from. It’s the sequel I never expected; maybe nobody did.And important distinction to make before discussing Bioshock 2’s narrative, is that the first game was first and foremost the story of the city of Rapture and its fall into madness through its own attempts to create a lawless utopia. In comparison, 2 is almost entirely focused around a very small cast of key characters; their relationships to each other, conflicting ideals, and eventual goals which clash with each other and create this very personal, self contained narrative, within which Rapture is merely a setting instead of the star.In some ways this is a good thing. By taking the focus off of Rapture and onto a new, very small collection of characters, developer 2K Marin is able to craft a more personal narrative, spending more time developing the characters that matter and the relationships between them. In other ways, it makes the time not spent directly advancing the plot far less impactful and memorable than they may otherwise have been. Characters outside the very core plot are introduced and then discarded in ways that feel contrived and unmemorable, moving you along but never leaving much of an impact outside of your immediate encounters with them. This also contributes to Rapture being a much less interesting, tangible place to explore, feeling stale and lifeless when at one point it was remarkably well crafted and intriguing.On the whole, the narrative is rather significantly less mentally stimulating, disregard the deeper themes of ideology, morality, and freedom that gave the original such an astounding sense of scope and inspired so much discussion about the different ideas laced within the game. Bioshock 2 tries to mimic what Irrational Games did so deftly, but it comes out as something superfluously intelligent; tossing about grand ideas in the background of a fairly simple plot that never attempts more than it can feasibly accomplish. Simplicity isn’t a bad thing by nature, as the story is still engaging and arguably easier to follow, but I rather missed the more sophisticated philosophical questions posed by the original that was so substantially more contemplative and inspired.  The change to a strictly linear world design was also rather disappointing to me, as though there are logical narrative reasons you wouldn’t be able to return to locations after you went through them, it’s yet another thing taken away from the original that causes Rapture to feel like a rather hollow environment. It’s still full of the same distinctive artwork, excellent sense of place, and fitting music, but it feels so soulless compared to what it once was that it makes returning to Rapture again almost dull at times. There are things later on which actually add interesting, fundamental aspects to the city’s lore, but by that point it’s almost too late and the moment will likely be lost or overlooked by most.Whether the changes are improvements or make up for what was lost is debatable, though by and large the plot failed to leave the impression the original did, despite being well written and interesting in its own right. Perhaps its the issue of being in the shadow of such a monumental achievement that was Bioshock, that anything to come after that isn’t as incredibly feels significantly more of a disappointment that it otherwise would. Had 2 been released as in a vacuum I may have been more receptive to what it was attempting to do, but with the weight of its predecessor on its shoulders there was just - something - missing to draw me in quite the same way as I was to the original.Where 2 far surpasses the original though is through the numerous refinements and additions it makes to the mechanics, turning Bioshock from a brilliantly deep and satisfying shooter, into a smoother, even deeper shooter that streamlines and polishes off the few rough edges of the original. The core of the combat is largely unchanged, utilizing a mixture of firearms and plasmids (essentially superpowers) to take down a variety of different splicers (the enemies of the game), but the introduction of dual wielding, the ability to instantly switch ammo types, a collection of interesting new weapons, a significantly faster and less cumbersome hacking system,  and a scaled back but even more customizable tonic (passive upgrades) system do a lot to make Bioshock 2 a much faster and enjoyable experience.They’re small changes for the most part to be sure, but collectively add up to a much tighter shooting experience that makes it hard for me to imagine returning to the comparatively clunky original. Encounters with the most prominent new enemy, Big Sisters, is another brilliant twist on something the original began (in this instance the Big Daddy fights, which also return), as quicker, more capable and powerful enemies that present a large challenge and require you change your tactics as they are far more versatile and aggressive than their older counterparts.These improvements make Bioshock 2 one of the most enjoyable and dynamic shooters I’ve ever played. Where it falters in its storytelling and world building, it makes up for with the sheer entertainment to be found in its combat, which only grows as the game goes on. It might not wholly surpass the original, but it surely approaches it in a lot of ways, which is something I scarcely imagined there was any possibility it could. In some ways it feels more akin to an update than an entire new experience, but when that update is so fun and smartly designed I can't complain.On multiplayer…Surprising though it may be, 2K has fitted a multiplayer mode within Bioshock 2, and even more unexpectedly it’s not terrible! More than that, it’s actually a rather enjoyable mode that while totally derivative of every other first-person multiplayer shooter in terms of modes, progression, and character customization, it transposes the campaigns fantastic shooting into a multiplayer mode almost entirely intact. Your weapons and abilities might be slightly neutered, but the combat is so strong at its core that I found myself spending a surprising amount of time with the mode and enjoying every moment of it. Bioshock as a shooter is almost completely unreplicated in any other game, so having that in a multiplayer mode that even in every other aspect is fairly uninteresting is rather compelling, and most certainly worth checking out despite its dubious inclusion.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

												James Cameron's Aliens (1986) isn't as handsome or terrifying as Ridley Scott's Alien (1979), it doesn't have the same dreary beauty or pioneering tone (and the new aliens look cheap by comparison), but Aliens is a hell of a lot more fun to watch. It's also more moving, and maybe the better movie. Bioshock 2 is the same, and I think better than Bioshock 1 in almost every way that matters. Bioshock introduced the world and set the tone magnificently, but it was only half of a good game. Bioshock 2 gets the combat and enemies right, locations are more dynamic and the plot actually has stakes. It felt like I was fighting for something meaningful by the end, and I felt like more than just a guy with a gun/drill. And the Little Sisters are stunning characters. They're terrifying and memorable every time, and even when they're not around you're dreading the your next encounter, preparing, remembering escape plans, stocking up on ammo and health. After surviving all the mad things in Rapture, you'll inevitably face a Little Sister. You get to choose when and where you'll fight, and this mix of fear, adrenaline and tactics is really special for an FPS. Yeah, the graphics took noticeable a downgrade and nothing here matches the opening minutes of Bioshock 1, but everything else is an improvement and it's a shame more people don't know that.

 Bioshock 2 Review + How To Fix the Game Crashing  Without any spoilers Game Grade: A-Shorthand Review: Battle against hordes of murderous splicers in the decaying, or more accurately, the decayed city of rapture.  Bioshock 2 will force you to choose between your survival or your morals.Detailed Review:Personally, Bioshock is my favorite series.  You can ask any one of my friends and they will reluctantly agree.  If you have not played the first Bioshock, then I highly recommend that you play it first.  They must be played in order to understand everything.  Bioshock 2 has just about everything the first one had, but I do not want to compare them too much.  There are different endings you can achieve depending on how you play the campaign.  Also, the storyline (which will not be spoiled) is the 'at the end of your seat' game play we all enjoy.  The map tends to be large which gives you countless options on new places to explore.  Bioshock 2 is a wonderfully gripping sequal.The first detail I would like to talk about is the replay value.  If you have read some of my other reviews, then you would know I talk about this a lot.  Replay value, to me, really makes a game worth your money.  As you may know, Bioshock is known to have different endings which rely on choices you make in the game.  There are multiple decisions you need to make throughout the game.  Some of those decisions are more difficult than the others.  To really get your money's worth out of this game, you should play to get every ending.  This will require many hours of game play, but each time you play it will seem like a brand new game.  There is also another game mode you can play called the 'Protector Trials'.  I am going to put this the best way I can.  Its hard.Another point I would like to make on Bioshock 2 is the storyline.  Bioshock 2 is considered a "weak" sequel to many people.  Although it is not as good as the first, it was a necessary sequal to the series.  Bioshock 2 focuses on the desperate power grab for the keys to Rapture.  I don't really want to spoil anything so I will leave it at that.Finally, I would like to address the map.  You can expect as much exploration in Bioshock 2 as the first Bioshock (a lot).  There are many secondary objectives and secret rooms just waiting to be found.  You can almost here their faint sceams.. "Find me.  Please... find me."  This is another reason why I think it has great replay value.  By exploring the map to the fullest, you will be greatly rewarded in more ways than one.  One thing that you should not expect to change in this game is potential exploration.  The map is a maze and you are the mouse.Overall, the game is enjoyable with countless hours of possible game play.  Although it may not be as good as the first, it is still a clear Bioshock game.  There is still a 'horror' factor involved with the murderous splicers (as in the first game).  This game is definitely worth the time and money as long as you pay attention and find the cules.  I hope this review helped anyone thinking about buying this game.  If this did not help, then let me know by posting a comment.I made the overall review a bit short to help people out with the common problem of crashing.  To “fix” the game crashing and you losing your progress, save the game every couple of minutes.  The beginning is the main place the game will crash.  Once you get about 15 minutes into the game, the crashing should not be a problem.  If you need more help on how to fix it, then post a comment and I will do my best to help you out.

												Bioshock 2 is viewed as the black sheep of the "Shock" franchise, created as a cheap cash-in sequel by a different development team that crafted the first Bioshock.  But beyond the initial impressions from fans and critics lies a very competent game, that in some spots actually outshines the original.Good Stuff:-The story is just as good, if not better, than the original.  Most people disliked the story because it didn't add much depth to the mythos of Rapture, but the story in Bioshock 2 is much more personal and is more about the citizens of Rapture than the city itself.-The gameplay is vastly improved.  Plasmids and Guns are duel wielded, making combining them in combat much easier.  -Mechanics are streamlined, not simplified.  Gene tonics no longer have a type and can just be equipped, assuming you have the slots.  Hacking is now done in real time on a simplified  mini-game.  Even the research mechanic is reworked to use a video-camera that gives you more research points depending on how well you combo your plasmids/weapons.  There are also new weapons and plasmids that are fun to use and don't feel gimmicky.-The art design is top notch.  The level designers have fun showing what rapture would look like with 10 more years of rust and decay.-More moral decisions beyond "Save/Kill Little Sister".  The game also uses your decisions to inform the last act of the game and the ending.-Final "boss" fight is much better than the one in the first game.Bad Stuff:-The first hour of the game stinks. Period.  After you get into the first real level, the game begins to open up and let you start having fun.-Some of the new characters have to be hand waved into existence, especially since they were supposed to be around before the first game but are clearly never mentioned in the first game.-Levels are much more linear and not as large as in the first game. There are few sidepaths, but mostly you'll be running from point A to B without backtracking.-There are a few new enemies but I would have liked more enemy variety.-You can use little sisters to gather Adam, but you have to protect them as they do it.  Most people hated the escort mission from the first game, so it's something to be aware of.   I personally enjoyed this part of the game due to the multitude of alternate amunition that makes setting up traps fun.-It's clear that there were some significant rewrites late in development, some characters introduced at the start of the game are simply left out of the rest of the game's plot.Ugly Stuff:-The FoV is very low and requires ini-rebinding to reset it every time you launch the game.  The problem is going into ironsights also resets the FoV, making you have to press your bound key to reset your FoV every time.-Occasional issues with audio cutting out if there were too many sounds are playing at once. Verdict:Ignore people saying the game is a cheap cash in: the gameplay is better and arguably so is the story.  Although there are fewer levels than in the original, the game actually took me more hours to beat than the first game: around 14 hours.  It’s also interesting that a lot of the story beats and themes end up being used in Bioshock Infinite (although I’m sure Ken Levine hates to admit it).Minerva's Den is also an excellent add-on to the base game, and lasts around 3 hours.  I'd recommend playing through Bioshock 2 on hard mode if you've played many shooters before, the difficulty curve stays pretty good throughout the entire base game.  Minerva's Den is a bit harder on the same difficulty however, so keep that in mind.

												BioShock 2 is good.  Not exactly a surprise given the content of other available reviews on Steam, but why is it good seems the more important thing, something I'll try to address here.  I'm going to tell you why I think BioShock 2 is a worthy successor in the series.First things first, to get right down to brass tacks BioShock 2 is a sequel, it is mostly more of the same gameplay (with a few twists) and the few innovations don't exactly break the bank in the inventiveness department.  A few new weapons and interesting plasmid variations and a small smattering of new enemy types don't do much to dispel the notion that the combat is totally more BiShock.  But that's not what makes a BioShock game, not really.  Sure, the combat has to be engaging enough to drive the narrative forward, but in this game it does that just enough.  No, much like the first, the true draw is the dark and twisted story, the narrative tapestry that shows the dark and twisted nature of those living in Rapture.This game has you playing as a Big Daddy, the stalwart if myopic defenders of the Little Sisters.  In particular, you play a “prototype”, a nameless everyman changed into a monster but also a kind of father, and it is the theme of fatherhood that, like the first game, shares the roost with a political ideology to form the basis of the disastrous tale of the fall of Rapture.  Where the first game gazed on what genetics truly determine, on the pure unbridled force of Libertarianism and Capitalism, this game focuses on what it means to be a parent, and the equal sociopolitical dangers of a Communistic ideal that crosses the line into religious fervor.  It is the other side of the coin to Andrew Ryan's Rapture ideal of the individual's power in Rapture, the ideal of not just the social as one entity in a metaphorical manner, but what might happen if science could allow us all to actually become one.  And just as in the first game, the dangers of extremist politics show how such ideas can rip a society, and in particular a family apart.This is the crux of the story: as the first game contained two father figures for the original protagonist, the Big Daddy is one of two parent figures presented in the game. Unlike before where you were being acted upon as a child with two parental figures, now you are one of the agents of change, and your actions effect the story in a more noticeable (if still superficial) manner.It also drips the kind of scary, jarring atmosphere that is at once engaging to behold and terrifying to think about, the constructive and destructive nature of humankind.  Water drips, walls crack, but unlike before the underwater world outside Rapture is at least nominally explored, and it is beautiful, but sadly littered with the detritus of the once grand city.  The decay of the amazing city of Rapture is at once enthralling and disturbing, an emotional range that was demonstrated in BioShock, and is absolutely in full effect here.To add to the positives Minerva's Den, a small DLC adventure contained within this game, is a wonderful look at how every last person in Rapture was hurt, changed, damaged by the vision of Andrew Ryan.  Rapture is a crucible and all it seems to produce is tragedy, and each game with it as it's setting allows us to see something of ourselves in it's tragedy.  With arresting visuals, a story just as dark as it's sibling, and the upgraded combat engine, this game is well worth the time.  It is the other side of the coin, the “2” in this case being a quite literal extension of the first, and that is a very good thing indeed.

												Bioshock 2 is a FPS developed and published by 2K Games and is the sequel and successor of Bioshock. Most people think the first game is better than the sequel , but i disagree. In my opinion the sequel improves on everything from the first game alongside adding more interesting and developed characters and story.The Story (Spoiler Free)Bioshock 2 takes place after the events of the first game although the OPENING of the game is set 2 years prior the events of the first one.BioShock 2 opens on New Year's Eve 1958 (two years before the events of the first game), as Subject Delta patrols Rapture with his Little Sister, Eleanor. Eleanor is separated from Delta by her mother, Sofia Lamb, who uses a mind control plasmid on Delta to make him shoot himself. Ten years later, Delta awakens, revived by Little Sisters under the control of Eleanor. Delta is drawn towards Eleanor by their past Big Daddy-Little Sister connection. Brigid Tenenbaum encounters Delta, and explains that unless Delta reunites with Eleanor, he will fall into a coma. With the help of the Little Sisters under Eleanor's control and Tenenbaum's ally, Augustus Sinclair, Delta makes his way towards Lamb's stronghold.GameplayThe game is a FPS with RPG elements to it which includes both singleplayer and multiplayer modes although multiplayer is    totally dead nowadays so i'll skip talking about it. The game has a total of 6 weapons , each with significant weapon upgrades. Unlike the first one , the sequel doesn't allow you to upgrade every weapon to the max although once you pick and upgrade your favourite weapon , you won't really need anything the others. The game also comes with 2 tools: Hack Tool and Research Camera , who both help you greatly on your journey. Unlike the first game , the resources in this one are plenty , so you'll have a chance to buy almost every upgrade and plasmid out there. There are a total of 11 plasmids in this game which most can be upgraded to level 3. Unlike the first game , in order to upgrade a plasmid to level 3 here , you first need to have bought the level 2 version of that certain plasmid , but don't worry , the currency you buy the plasmids with is plentyful depending on if you know what you're doing. The game has several endings depending on if you decide to save or gather the little sisters/spare or kill the people you meet along the way. GraphicsFor a game that was released in 2010 the graphics are pretty good. They sure do bring that creepy and abandoned atmosphere the game offers alive.SoundtrackOne of my favourite soundtracks in a game , the musicians definitely gave their best when they were making it. Here's one of my favourite tracks of the game:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u2d8TVBameoComplaintsMy only complaints are that the game tends to crash at random when you save , so save as often as possible , i warned ya! ^^ There's also a chance that if it crashes right when you save , it may corrupt your save file in which case you gotta find the corrupted save file and delete otherwise the game is unplayable. Only happened to me twice through my playthrough but i tend to ignore it.Overall:The game took me around 30 hours to 100% all of it's singleplayer achievements and all of them were very enjoyable. This is one of my all-time favourite FPS games , i totally recommend you to buy it! If you haven't played it yet YOU ARE COMMITTING A SIN!I rate a total of 10/10 and mind you , i actually mean it unlike all those kids out there claiming "10/10" on so many things they aren't even sure they likehttp://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=712033396Now would you kindly buy this game and give my review a like? :)

												In the underwater metropolis of Rapture, lies one of the most exhilerating, tense and memorable experiences that will always be known in the history of gaming. Bioshock 2 tells the untold story of Subject Delta, the Big Daddy who broke free, the Big Daddy that everyone has turned against, and his relationship with a specific little sister of Rapture, Eleanor. 2K Games has designed a game that expands Bioshock's mythology, but doesn’t lose any of the mystery. A game that introduces fascinating new settings and characters, but doesn’t forget or neglect those previously established. A game that gives the player devastating new power, but balances that with devastating new fear. A game that takes chances and makes changes, but almost always for the better. Playing as a big daddy, Bioshock brings destructive and fast paced arcade combat with the help of creative plasmids, setting alight, lifting trash cans and hypnotizing every single big daddy you come across. But in this mysterious dystopia, exploration is key feature to the immersion and overall enjoyment of this title, whether it is the hunting of little sisters, being hunted by big sisters or the spamming of the 'search' button. Much like its predecessor, BioShock 2 is slower and more methodical than your average shooter, but combat feels much more natural and effective than it ever did before. But I never said it would be easy.......nononononono. Being a Big Daddy sure does make you a badass but at the same time a vulnerable slow target that is very well suited to the games strengths. Rapture is a dark, dismal world that envelopes you with a blanket of isolation, excellent art direction, a great soundtrack, and a fantastic voice cast all team up with a powerful story to create an atmosphere so thick and intense that it is at times downright chilling.

The only humanity left are insane and blood thirsty, addicted to a gene modifying drug called ADAM. Your little coma preventing girl is now a teenager, and you need to traverse the collapsing Rapture in order to reconnect with her. All the while her mother is sending the entire city in a religious frenzy to stop you at all costs.It's a pretty cheerful game.All jokes aside, I couldn't recommend this game enough. It's a solid and atmospheric sequel to the more philosophical Bioshock, but with improved combat, and visuals. You'll have to explore a more linear world than before, but the set peices and earie vibe more than make up for it. Definitely a must play if you're a fan of the Bioshock series, or just a general fan of shooters, horror, and want to call your games High Art.8.3 / 9

BioShock 2 deserves more loveLet me cut straight to the chase. Is BioShock 2 as memorable as BioShock? Perhaps not. Is the story as amazing? No. Is the story flawed in some senses? Yes. Is it a bad game? No, absolutely not. BioShock 2 is great in it's own right. It maintains most of the fantastic elements found in BioShock but (in my opinion) improves game-play in several ways.Positive:- Still fantastically atmospheric- Main story is OK BUT the story in Minerva's Den (DLC) is incredible.- Minerva's Den is really worth your time- One plasmid and one weapon equipped at the same time. YESSSSSSSSS!- Hacking system is greatly improved- Hacking from a distance!- Exploring is still as rewarding as ever - you'd be surprised how many places you can go- BioShock 2 is challenging, especially fights with Big Daddies/SistersNegative:- Main story is not as memorable as BioShock- You have to fight Big Sisters, even if you choose not to harvest Little Sisters (this makes no sense to me). But fighting them is still enjoyable.- I did not enjoy the multiplayer scene. There were very few players and some players were already at max level. Let me tell you, it is extremely difficult to play against someone with so many advantages. It is a shame because the concept is really solid. Conclusion:If you enjoyed BioShock I would urge you to give BioShock 2 a try too. Yes, the reviews are not as positive as they are for BioShock, but what really matters is your personal enjoyment of the game. I can say that I certainly enjoyed playing BioShock 2, and I think you would too.

er 17, 2014
-Quick Review-BioShock 2 is a First Person Shooter sequel to BioShock, the second game was released  3 years after the original (Release date: Feb 9,  2010). The game feels very much like you've returned to the city "Rapture" for more game play, however events are taking place about 10 years after those that transpired in BioShock 1. -Detailed breakdown review-Story:  Welcome back to Rapture, please keep your arms, legs, and morality inside your big daddy suit the whole time and enjoy the ride! Jesting aside, this game is dark and twisted... which is what most people seem to love about it.In this game you play as a "Big Daddy" (Basically the guy you see on the cover art, big armored behemoths) named Delta who is searching for his "little sister" (those little girls with the red demon eyes) named Eleanor.Just like in the last game as you play you unlock new abilities, weapons, upgrades for your weapons, and ("force skills that require that blue stuff" Sorry, I can't help myself) Plasmids that require EVE to use. The game is very linear with no going backwards through levels, the game is rather challenging (unless you relish huge challenges, in that case this game is probably too passive for you. Basically the difference in difficulty is just how hard your enemies hit, not AI difficulty etc.)Game Play: Controls for this game are standard, the big difference between 1 and 2 is that you can keep more passive abilities called "Gene Tonics" active. There are a couple new weapons and a handful of new Gene Tonics.The starting weapons are the same ones you had in BioShock1, I don't want to spoil any of the next weapons just know they're fun, but I tend to find myself sticking with the bread and butter weapons. There are new secondary ammo types, for several of the weapons. I won't lie, I really like setting traps.It should be noted that I felt like I was playing in the exact same city, graphic-wise the whole city feels exactly the same with small changes. I don't like to talk about graphics in video games but for me this actually did feel like a continuation of the first BioShock Game.   Achievements: There are three types of achievement categories in this game: single player main story, Multiplayer competitive, and DLC. At this time I'm still working on many of the achievements (12/17/14) I have a majority of the single player achievements, nothing unusual to report on these achievements. The multiplayer ones require playing until max online level, so that will be a bit of a grind, it is also oftentimes difficult to find people to play with (depends on the time of day). Lastly DLC achievements, which I have always felt is a cheap way to get more life out of a game. (Blame the sims3 and EA, okay? That's why I'm so cynical about paying for DLC. haha) Price:  BioShock 2 is priced at $19.99, I acquired my copy from a Humble Bundle, so as usual I recommend getting the game on a steam sale or in a humble bundle. Since this is an old game, if you don't already own it I recommend waiting for a 75% off or better sale.As far as quality is concerned, I have 14 hours in this game and about half of the achievements, I think it's close to a good buy if you're just playing through the game once, if you're going to play on a higher difficulty, or through the game multiple times this game is a very good quality. Conclusion: Story = Awesome. Game Play = Effortless, natural and fluid to play. Achievements = Meh...could be better. Price = Fair. This game tends to appeal to people who like First person shooters and story games, with the addition of multiplayer it could appeal to the competitive crowd but there aren't nearly as many people actively playing.I recommend this game for people who like darker stories, and tend to enjoy first person shooters, regardless of their difficulty. Rapture will warp your perceptions of "right and wrong"; as always, I've been impressed by the story.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update April 10, 2015:Here's the URL to see my review for BioshockHere's the URL to see my review for Bioshock Infinite

												Sequel 101: Take the original and make it bigger, better and more violent. Bioshock 2 covers its bases well with expanded gameplay, stage design and enemy variation. The story lacks the surprise twist from the original, but it makes up for it in buckets by simply being a better game. The original Bioshock was a surprise hit from 2007. It offered incredible atmosphere, a riveting story and entertaining gameplay. All the ingredients for an instant classic. The sequel had a lot to live up and it took a slightly different approach. Incredible atmosphere, an entertaining story and literally riveting gameplay. For the sequel you get to play as a big daddy, the huge lumbering divers on the game’s cover. Arguably the most intelligent design choice for a sequel since Terminator 2. Bioshock 2 is an insane power fantasy. You play as an armoured badass in the run down districts of the once shining city of Rapture. You are subject Delta, an old cover model and you are called back from the beyond to rescue your daughter from some head-shrink. Yeah, the story is a bit thin, but your motivation is clear: Save your daughter from a psycho and kill, murder and maim anyone who gets in your way. Playing as the big poppa gives you access to the iconic drill, a rivet gun (earlier pun intended), a huge machine gun, an elephant gun that has no business being fired from the hip, a spear gun taken from the bow of a whaler and a rocket launcher that probably fell of an armoured truck. In your other hand you command the forces of nature to shock, roast and freeze your enemies. You are a one man army and you are not going to let anyone get in your way. To compensate, the enemies are more numerous and aggressive. You’ll often fight against dozens while also hacking and setting traps at the same time. You’ll also brave gauntlets against an incoming tide of enemies while you defend your little sister helper while she’s gathering valuable power-up juice. The addition of these standoffs is a welcome one and adds some serious meat to the gameplay. Setting traps allows for some really creative tricks. This goes on from start to finish and gets more intense along the way. No difficulty falloff here. Difficulty in general; Bioshock 2 is quite challenging in its own right. Enemies hit hard and never stop attacking. So even on normal does it present a good challenge (unlike Infinite’s 1999 mode, which was as easy as shooting fish in a barrel.) Furthermore, the city of Rapture looks just as gorgeous as before. Ok, maybe the textures are a bit washed out, but when the place is flooded, everything looks washed out. One major problem persists the game and that is the stability. Bioshock 2 has a nasty habit of crashing to desktop for no apparent reason. I’m still vexed as to why it happens, but it annoys the living hell out of me and it has me save every ten minutes to prevent losing all that progress. Also, the controls are somewhat of a mess. You’ll have to tinker with them, but its manageable. There’s also a multiplayer mode…which I’m not even touching. I came here to drill people and save little sisters; and that’s just what this game lets you do.

												Sequals usually fall flat when people play them. Not very often does a sequal come by that impresses and wins over an original games audience. Lets face it, Bioshock 2 is a cash in on the success of Bioshock. Despite this, it does not fail as game, nor as a sequel. The overall gameplay of this game is far superier to that of the original. The weapon variety maybe not as diverse, and the weapon designs do not change drastically like the original, but still good weapons nonetheless. I mean, what other game can you play as zeus in a metal diving suit, with a gatling gun? In addition to this, the balence is better, the research process is better thought out, plasmids are not stupidly OP anymore, and you can actually get some neat tonics and upgrades to your Big Daddy. The little sister and escort sections are not tedious anymore either, they offer a nice break from the monotony of the main story. This is broken up with some nice tea parties with  former co-workers of yours, and some swims in the community fish tank. The games pacing is fluid from beginning to end, and does not chug at any point, unlike the original.Originally, my main criticism of Bioshock 2, is that it did not have that "AHA" moment the original had. Well lets just say that the DLC Mirvenas Den solves that problem. Everything I thought Bioshock 2 was lacking, that DLC contained. What it did, is offered that "AHA" moment that made the original so good. At first, I thought the DLC ending would be generic and terrible, only to find out the big plot twist at the end. This twist, along with the ending area/cutscene, offers a conclusive end to the rapture experiance. It finally wraps up the city in a satisfying way, something, neither game alone could do.In short, this game improves upon even facet of the original, maybe not to a shine, but certainly to some degree, and offers a conclusive ending to the original Bioshock series/Rapture. Giving this God-Forsaken underwater dystopia, finally a sense of peace.

Bioshock 2 takes a pair we basically just saw as objects in the game previously A Big Daddy and his Little Sister, then put us in the shoes of the Big Daddy. r 8, 2016
												Okay, so I've finished BioShock 2 twice now, with different choices and on different consoles.Let me break it down for you.BioShock 2 has an insanely good campaign, utilizing every mechanic you're taught in very diverse ways. BioShock 2 isn't labelled as open world, but there is plenty of exploring to do. There's tons of secrets; whether it be easter eggs, items or audio tapes that reveal the truth about Rapture. The campaign is of average length, depending if you're a completionist or a speed runner. I tried to explore as much as I could, and the campaign took me 8 hours. The campaign is emotional and gripping and leaves you to think over about the events that just occured. It's incredibly immersive and really makes you feel like you are Subject Delta, a deep sea diver who wondered upon the underwater city of Rapture, where he was accepted but not fully trusted. This led to him getting surgically modified; giving him vocal cord modulator surgery and bonding him with his own Little Sister, thus dubbing him a Big Daddy. Also, choices matter which makes it even more immersive as you decide your fate. Overall, I would give the campaign a 9/10, lacking only in some graphical features and seeming rather repetitive in some cases. Still, a MUST PLAY.The multiplayer is very enjoyable. You take the role of plasmid-bearing citizens of Rapture, all utilizing their own looks and characteristics. There is a levelling system in multiplayer, which is pretty cool (only if you play ranked). There are tons of diverse game modes that can keep you rotating through different scenarious and giving flavour (I use UK spelling, sorry Americans) to the multiplayer. There are many multiplayer communities that actively host lobbies (you can check them out on my profile, set as my primary group) which are extremely fun to be a part of. The multiplayer flows very well and has that arcade-y, arena-y feel to it. The multiplayer, I give an 8/10, an intense, fast-paced FPS experience, totally different from campaign.To summarise, BioShock 2 is a great game and a must play. It's one of the best games I've ever played. Don't waste money on the remaster as it does not feature multiplayer and has little graphical improvement. BioShock 2 gets an 8.5/10 from me. Be sure to buy this masterpiece!

Sunken, sunken is BabylonI've heard that BioShock 2 is a 'simple shooter', failing in comparison with original BioShock, and I've learned it to be VERY far from truth. This is a great and unique game that actually made me fall in love with Rapture. Some minor spoilers ahead.The level design is superb. Set ~10 years after the end of BioShock, this game features Rapture that now truly became a sunken Babylon, beautiful and forlorn, mysterious and sad. The small underwater parts are a nice touch, I've always wanted to be able to travel the ocean floor! And the part where you are seeing Rapture through the eyes of the Little Sister is also perfect and very creepy, and it adds to the story a lot.And the story itself fits the setting perfectly, and is as interesting and rich as the BioShock's one, or even more so (it's hard to judge but BioShock2 had larger impact on me personally). There are more moral choices you make through the game (a man chooses! *wink wink*), and it helps you to immerse into the narrative, and the narrative reacts to these choices (frankly, hearing Sinclair say 'so a tin man had a heart of gold' made me tear a little). The music and voices are very good too.Gameplay is simply the best throughout the series. You have 8 different weapons/gadgets and 11 plasmids in 8 possible slots, and you can combine some of them (trap+elemental plasmids), and you also use security devices (dear flying bots, Alexander and Diego and Sean and Thoroughfare and Diana and the others I remember each and everyone of you you were my FRIENDS thank you oh I'm gonna cry now), and there are some physical upgrades of various types, and the fully upgraded plasmids felt POWERFUL. The controls and the map demand some getting used to but are handy overall (I hated plasmid/weapon change in BioShock and, though it is perfectly reasonable, having only 2 weapons and a few physical enhancements in Infinite seemed rather restrictive, also, having NO MAP was a nightmare). Some say that guarding Little Sisters while they gather ADAM seems repetitive but I actually liked this kind of challenge - it was fun (with a right touch of nervousness) to prepare the location for the splicers attack using traps and other countermeasures.Overall, I loved the bathysphere atmosphere of the game a lot. There are fewer outright scary moments than in BioShock, but the place itself seems... haunted. Dark, and lonely, and dying, and mutating. Babylon turning into Leviathan.Can you pull in the leviathan with a fishhook or tie down his tongue with a rope?Can you put a cord through his nose or pierce his jaw with a hook?Will he keep begging you for mercy? Will he speak to you with gentle words?Play it. Obey. OBEEEEY! Ahem. No, really, try it. Open the seashell and swallow the pearl. See it's glowing?

												"Would I recommend this game" is a difficult question. The game itself is good. It may be the weakest installment in the Bioshock franchise to date, but the weakest installment of an amazing series is still pretty great. The reason I decided to say "no" is because of the amount of crap I had to go through just to get the game to play. I have about 16 hours of playtime logged, and I'm willing to bet a good half of it was spent troubleshooting, checking to see if various fixes worked, replaying segments and sometimes entire levels... it got old, fast. For a game that's been out for so long to not have a single fix for everything is pretty inexcusable, especially one that you're expected to pay for. I ended up looking up various guides on Steam and 2K's support forum to get the game to work, uninstalling and reinstalling the game twice, uninstalling and reinstalling programs on my computer, tinkering with files, settings, and compatibility modes, even editing the .ini file itself. The most prominent issues I had were it constantly crashing shortly after starting the game (just when you get the rivet gun), on the loading screen to Siren Alley, the loading screen for Fontaine Futuristics, and near the end of the Fontaine Futuristics level. All of these required multiple attempts on my part to fix and finally finish.On the other hand, my closest friend also has the Steam version of this game and reports not having the same problems. But for any game to give anyone this much problem, I wouldn't recommend spending your money on a roll of the dice to see whether or not it'll work (for the record, I had no problems with the original Bioshock, so don't assume that just because you played through that with no problems, you won't encounter issues here). It's truly upsetting that what could, and should, have been a pleasant, fun gaming experience turned into a frustrating nightmare, and as soon as I got to the ending, I uninstalled and washed my hands of it. Multiplayer? Other endings? Achievements? Forget about it, not worth the grief.If you do decide to give it a shot (in which case I recommend a console version), here's what I thought, issues getting the game to run aside: like I said, it may be the weakest link in Bioshock's Great Chain, but that doesn't mean it's a total waste of time. A lot of the gameplay was simplified from the first game (such as hacking, researching, even the Tonics all being in one area instead of being in four categories with different slots you need to open), some undoubtedly for the better (it's telling hacking and researching didn't appear in Infinite) and some for the worst. There is the mechanic of carrying around Little Sisters and guarding them as they gather, akin to the ending of the first game only much faster and less frustrating (with tonics to maximize ADAM and speed up the process becoming available fairly early). However, there's up to three Little Sisters per level, and each one can gather up to twice. It's really up to you how you decides to handle them, as in the original, but the fact remains you're still going to have to throw down with a Big Daddy and you're still going to have to deal with them somehow if you want ADAM.The main point that this game got a lot of flack for was the story. The game was, admittedly, a cash grab/attempt to keep the Bioshock name alive while Ken Levine and Take-Two/Irrational were working on Infinite, farmed out to 2K Marin. I, personally, think they did a decent enough job with what they had. The story lacked the symbolism and social commentary that made the first one so powerful, and a lot of the mystique and creepiness that Rapture had during the first outing is absent here. I won't even claim the story made total sense in the end (you pretty much need all the supplemental materials, including the dubiously canon novel Bioshock: Rapture by John Shirley, which did have input from Ken Levine, to make it close to solid). And, to quote the venerable Yahtzee, the original Bioshock's story didn't really need a direct sequel. But I wouldn't say the whole thing is a wash, either. For one thing, there's at least two moments in this game (I won't give spoilers) that I personally felt were some of the most powerful in the entire series to date.It really seems like when they were at the drawing board, whether intentionally or not, 2K Marin got it in their head that in making a game that wasn't basically an exact rehash of the first, they needed to make it as different as possible, and ended up creating the original on Opposite Day. WHAT FOLLOWS ARE SPOILERS FOR THE FIRST GAME!Whereas in Bioshock, you play a man that starts out with nothing and gradually finds his purpose throughout the game, in Biooshock 2, the main character has lost everything, including his identity (he's a Big Daddy), and is on a desperate journey, whether out of compulsion or genuine concern, to reclaim the one thing he had left. Whereas Andrew Ryan was a staunch objectivist who constantly extolled the value of looking out for yourself and acting in your own self-interest, the main villain of this game, Sofia Lamb, is a collectivist, with a cult built around being utterly selfless and willing to lay down your life if it would better serve mankind as a whole. Throughout the first game, you're guided by a man who seems kind, helpful, and sincere, but ultimately betrays you and reveals you were an unwitting pawn in his grand plan all along. In Bioshock 2, you're largely guided by a man who is a confessed and mostly unrepentant sleezeball, who makes no secret of the fact that he's mostly using you as a means to get him out of Rapture as well so he can profit off of the technology there. As he knows his plans hinge on you achieving your goal, he's willing to play ball. And let me add that 2K Marin deserves some major props for making a character that is so slimy, yet ultimately charming and likable.All in all, it's a fun game. You won't miss anything for skipping it, especially now that Infinite is out, and I personally wouldn't blame you if you decided to give it a pass and not bother with this slightly subpar installment in the franchise. But with 2K Marin now in charge of the franchise as a whole, it might be worth it if you're a fan of the series just to see how they've handled it in the past. Just, for the love of little yellow duckies, play it on a console and don't waste your time, money, and possibly hours of frustration trying to play the Steam version.

content:
13, 2016
												BioShock 2, the very definition of a misunderstood sequel!And so here I was, about 4 years after I played the original BioShock for the first time (the one on steam was the second) and was left amazed by the marvellously haunting underwater world and history of Rapture, the time had come to see how the story moved on.Truth be told, I am by nature negatively biased towards sequels of great games, since the result rarely is on par with the originals.At the same time, from online reviews and friends opinions I was expecting a generally mediοcre sequel, not really bad, but a lot inferior.What I got instead was a great game that was a lot reminiscent of its predecessor and that at the same time managed to put it's own touch and distinguish itself from it!The game is vastly big, since, except from its main single player story, which is already long enough to be comparable to the first one's, it also includes a multiplayer campaign, plus two more DLCs, so let me analyze them one by one!- The single player campaign, for starters: you start out as a Big Daddy (an older model of it actually), with it's two trademark weapons (the drill and the rivet gun) and the ability to escort Little Sisters at their ADAM gatherings, which I found to be a really nice idea to stand out from the first game, since it gave you the opportunity to see the world from a different perspective.The story is a bit confusing at first, you don't know who you are and what you are doing and I'll admit that, while I initially liked that, as the game progressed on this "amnesia" of sorts got a bit tiresome, since it prevented you from enjoying the story and its (small) twists.The first game was ahead in that aspect, since it made you start out pretty much confident about who you were and what you were doing, only to destroy that all at its half, with an amazing twist, one of the best of its kind. However the remaining half of the original BioShock wasn't as thrilling as the first one, though it definitely wasn't bad, just decent.Now, BioShock 2 took another route, to the end of the game you get to know very few things about the protagonist, as, little by little, you learn something more, all until the final levels, where the big twist kicks in and you find all the truth about yourself! The twist was, maybe, just a little inferior from the one of the first game, but it was still very good.Continuing on, aside from the story, the game made some great additions in the gameplay, that improved a lot the old one. For starters, the weapons/plasmids system was positively changed a bit, making them easier to handle, while at the same time new weapons and plasmids were added, greatly differentiating themselves from the older ones.Speaking of gameplay, when I first played Dishonored (another great game) I remember describing it as a "stealth based BioShock", well... upon playing BioShock 2 I found even more similarities to Dishonored than the first game and not just in gameplay, but storywise too (ie, in Dishonored you have to save a little girl named Emily and in BioShock 2 one named Eleanor). After all, Arkane Studios was involved in the making of both games, so that probably played its part. However, there too, Dishonored took it's own distinctive path, so I wouldn't call it a ripoff, in fact it even improved on many of these similarities that I noticed between said games (like a fast teleporting plasmid present in BioShock 2's multiplayer, named Aerodash, which was a lot similar to the vastly superior Blink ability in Dishonored... and how much I missed that ability in BioShock 2... ).Moving on, aside from the improved weapon and plasmid mechanics and some new splicers, BioShock 2 introduced an amazing foe: the Big Sister, who essentially was an evolution of the Big Daddy! I found them great for a change in the game's world, since they were really tough to beat and getting ready to "greet" them was scary enough, sometimes (I even remember getting ready to fight one and getting my ♥♥♥ kicked, only to be saved by, not one, but two cluelessly walking Big Daddies, that, upon being caught in the Big Sister's attacks, started attacking her as well, saving my lucky self!).Another big change in the gameplay was the ability to "wirelessly" hack machines, a change which I ended up really appreciating, despite the hack being done in real time, with enemies potentially attacking you.The graphics and soundtrack were, more or less, similar to the first's, with the former being slighly improved, but nothing too great. In itself that was a good thing, since it made the game stay closer to its predecessor.The game's levels dimensions were also changed, since the first game had many levels split in two parts (maybe because of limitations PCs had at that time), while BioShock 2 had 9 huge levels, which I mistakenly thought to be few at first, though being slightly smaller in total.Lastly, the game's main antagonist wasn't as thrilling as the two ones of the original BioShock, but she was good enough.Thankfully the final levels, upon learning your true identity and onwards, were quite good and action packed, so much that they even provided you with a great ally, which I won't spoil and I'll let you discover for yourself (for a single level you also got to play as a Little Sister, which was cool)!The ending was, once again, faithful to the original, where some of your choices in the game affected its outcome (much like in Dishonored, too).- Changing subject, I'll now go to the multiplayer campaign: overall, I didn't feel satisfied by it and that being because the game had some, difficult enough, multiplayer achievements, while at the same time it was not optimized well enough, resulting in a lot of lag (myself aside, I found others having the same problem too) and in almost empty lobbies, making the achievement hunt quite frustrating.However, that said, the multiplayer part was not all bad, it's gameplay was in fact quite good and balanced (though not entertaining enough) and it took part in a period before the events of the first BioShock, during Rapture's civil war, making it a bit more interesting.- And to the final part, we get to the game's two DLCs: the Protector Trials and Minerva's Den.The first one was not much related to the main story, but not totally unrelated too. Once again reminding me of Dishonored's first DLC (Dunwall City Trials), it comprised of many challenges were you once again assumed the role of a Big Daddy and had to protect a Little Sister during her ADAM gatherings, but with a specific set of weapons and plasmids each time, making the whole thing fun enough, while mixing just a bit of story in it and awarding you with some extra art and trailers of BioShock 2, for every succesful gathering you made.The second DLC was, instead, a continuation of the story and ended up being really good and long just enough to keep your interest on. You once again took the role of a Big Daddy with a mysterious story on its back, immersing yourself in the game's levels to find it out, all of this happening in another, unexplored, part of Rapture, with new weapons and enemies mixed in (the Ion Laser gun being its coolest addition).The DLC's ending was good enough, with the final twist being slightly more predictable than the main game's, but not too much, while at the same time providing a good closure to the world of Rapture.All in all, I found BioShock 2 to be a fantastic game and only slightly inferior to the original, most of it being due to the fact that you were already introduced and familiar to the world of Rapture from the latter. Hopefully the third game, BioShock Infinite, will manage to reignite the marvel of discovering a hidden city, this time in the sky (can't wait to play it as well)!But don't let that frighten you, since you are once again in for a Shock, so... would you kindly play BioShock 2?

												You can call me a hipster, but I like this one more than the original or Infinite. There's just something about this particular story, these particular characters and this particular Rapture, that was amiss in the other two. While Bioshock established Rapture as a location and told a story of its founder, Bioshock 2 focuses more on the lives of Rapture's ordinary inhabitants, and boy, does it add to the immersion. The storyline is less linear, allowing an option to spare or kill not only Little Sisters, but bosses as well, which leads to one of 6 endings.The core of the gameplay stayed almost untouched since the original Bioshock, but with some new features. Action-packed harvesting sessions and Big Sister fights are intertwined with the calm and tranquil seabed walks. In addition to previously seen weapons, you have Big Daddy's iconic drill and Rivet Gun at your disposal. Also, you can use both weapons and plasmids in a fight, without swapping one for the other (for me personally it seemed kind of stupid that it wasn't like this all along).In short, if you just finished Bioshock, and can't get enough of Rapture, get Bioshock 2 in a heartbeat. You won't regret it.Also, playing as a Big Daddy is beyond cool. 10 drill dashes out of 10.

ry 26, 2014
												BioShock 2 is one of my favourite games. Some time after it came out, I saw it was getting spit on and dismissed, but I didn't really pay attention to that, as I assumed it was the all too well known kneejerk reaction of the smug fanboy portion of the players.I got it and went in unbiased. I don't want to compare it to the others in terms of which I think is best, because I love them all separately and as a whole, but it does quite a few things better than the other two titles. What I can say is, I think 2 had the best combat out of the games, because there were so many possibilities, especially with the dual-wielding and the plasmid trap combos. That's not to say I think the combat in 1 or Infinite wasn't good; in fact, I liked it in both games, although less in Infinite. Of course, the latter had a variety of Vigor and weapon combos as well, but not nearly as big as 2.BioShock 2 also improved on many mechanics like the Camera, plasmid use, hacking, Little Sister interactions, upgrading, as well as things like the visuals and more. However, what I most love about it is the bond I felt with Eleanor and how my actions actually changed her character and demeanor. I really wanted to help her, I wanted her to be safe. And seeing the statues of me rescuing the NPCs through the Little Sister's eyes really made me emotional, as did the whole Little Sister adoption and subsequent saving mechanics. It was so touching to see how playing a merciful, forgiving Delta changed how the NPCs reacted to you and pretty much established you as the most human character in the game, even though you were, as Sinclaire roughly put it, a "tin man". And who can forget the Big Sister fights? They were the ultimate test for your skills, weapons, plasmids. And the ending monologue Eleanor does for the best ending, as well as that pan of Rapture with the main theme of the first game and her saying, "And then, Father, the Rapture dream was over." Man. That was one of the several moments in the game where I teared up and felt introspective about the whole (at the time) BioShock world."The Ocean On His Shoulders". How fitting indeed.I really like Lamb as a villain as well, because she was so different, yet almost as well-designed as Andrew Ryan in some aspects.I was invested all the way throughout BioShock 2, as I was with 1 and Infinite. I went in without prejudice and I got one hell of a good game out of it, so I can strongly recommend it.

content:

												Review for Bioshock: Here.Review for Bioshock Remastered: Here.**Note: This is NOT a review for the Remastered version. If you would like to see my Bioshock 2 Remastered review, please click here.*Excuse the play hours. I've much more on console and the Remastered version.When Bioshock 2 was announced, it unleashed a shock-wave of excitement throughout the gaming community; its predecessor had been a monumental success, and people could not wait to see what the sequel had in store. Born three long years after the original title, it's safe to say that Bioshock 2 did not disappoint in terms of gameplay, visuals, and setting, although many fans agree that the plot and characters are not quite as memorable as those from the first installment.The game begins in the year 1958, two years prior to the events of the first Bioshock, and shows the main character that you play, known as Subject Delta, patrolling Rapture with his Little Sister, Eleanor. Some events happen, and the game fast forwards ten years later to the year 1968 (not 1970 as the store page misleads you to believe). Subject Delta, also known as Johnny Topside prior to his conversion into a Big Daddy, has set out to find Eleanor, who is now a young adult in her teens. Time is pressing, however, as the longer a Big Daddy is away from his Little Sister, the higher the odds of him slipping into a coma are. There's but one problem standing in your way, a highly manipulative and slightly insane woman named Sophia Lamb. She has replaced Andrew Ryan as the main antagonist, while Augustus Sinclair helps guide you throughout Rapture through radio messages. Yes, you read that right. This time around, you get to play as an actual Big Daddy; arguably the most appealing feature of the entire game. You can also take on other Big Daddies to take their Little Sisters, and you can protect them as they're harvesting ADAM from angels. After letting the Little Sister gather from two angels, you take her back to her vent and choose to either harvest or rescue her. Harvesting or rescuing Little Sisters has an impact on the end game cutscene, and there are a total of three different endings. New to the tried and true Splicers and Big Daddies are now Big Sisters, which wear much of the same gear as a Big Daddy but they're much slimmer, quicker, and deadlier.Another improvement to the gameplay is the ability to wield both a weapon and a Plasmid at the same time, where as in the original Bioshock you had to constantly swap between the two. However, there's a huge glitch in the game that causes your left arm, which is the one that uses Plasmids, to disappear until you either die or get talked to by Eleanor. There are also a new assortment of weapons, such as the drill, grenade launcher, and speargun, and there are a mix of new and old Plasmids to enjoy as well, 11 in total.Bioshock 2 feels a lot more linear than its predecessor, as there aren't as many non-essential rooms to explore. However, the lush environments and fantastic atmosphere more than make up for the overall closed maps. A huge feature, aside from being a Big Daddy of course, is being able to occasionally venture outside of Rapture, onto the ocean floor. The oceanic scenes and moments spent underwater are beautifully crafted, and make you realize just how small you are in comparison to the immense structure that is the city of Rapture. The Art Deco style has been down-scaled in this installment in lieu of a more steampunk style, which ends up coming full circle in Bioshock Infinite.One thing that really brought this game down was the inclusion of a multiplayer element. I'm not even sure if the servers are still active anymore, but I did play some multiplayer on console when the game was brand new. Like most games that should stay as a single player experience but don't, the multiplayer was terrible and mostly consisted of death matches between Big Daddies and Splicers. I'm not alone in my distaste for the multiplayer element, as you will see most other reviewers also scorn it as well. This 'feature', however, has been dropped in the Bioshock 2 Remastered version.Is Bioshock 2 better than the first game? Absolutely not. It's nowhere near as memorable in terms of story or plot, but the gameplay is where this title really shines. Playing as a Big Daddy is satisfying in every imaginable way, from the killing and being able to use a drill, to protecting Little Sisters and helping them harvest ADAM. It's the experience that fans would've been continuing to ask for until we got it, but luckily 2K had the foresight to just go ahead and do it. Sophia Lamb is definitely not as charming a villain as Andrew Ryan or Atlas, but she does have her moments. It's a worthwhile experience for the fan of the Bioshock universe, just don't go in expecting as gripping of a tale.Rating: 4.0/5.0 - Excellent, highly worth playing.𐌕𐋏𐌄 𐋏𐍈𐍂𐍂𐍈𐍂 𐌽𐌄𐌕𐤔𐍈𐍂𐌊 Curator | Group 𐌂𐌋𐌆𐌂𐌊 𐌅𐍈𐍂 𐌾𐍈𐍂𐌄
