content:
, 2014
This is a long review so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend BioShock 2 skip to Results and read from there.2K Games does it again with a beautiful story, fantastic gameplay, and wonderful internal environment. BioShock 2 has it all and pushes the greatness of the series to new heights.Story:Taking place after the original life has been brought back to the lost, but never forgotten city of Rapture. Professor Lamb has started working to bring young girls back down to the deep city and start cultivating Adam once again. Her idea of a utopia exists unlike Ryan’s which is based on uncontrolled capitalism Lambs is based on true altruism, the idea of the true utopia. You as one of the original Big Daddy’s have been brought back to life to save Eleanor, your Little Sister from a fate worse than death. Will you be able to make it in time?Campaign:There are nine levels: Adonis Luxury Resort, Atlantic Express, Ryan Amusements, Pauper’s Drop, Siren Alley, Dionysus Park, Fontaine Futuristics, Outer Persephone, and Inner Persephone. The levels in this campaign vary in length drastically, some of them being relatively short while others are overly massive. You have varying objectives in each area: find items, fight bosses, activate switches, find little sisters, etc. These keep the campaign interesting and each area has its own spin on how it wants you to play. The campaign is well laid out and each area has its own twists that make it unique. Gameplay:The game plays differently than the original, as you are no longer a mere mortal but rather one of the machines you fought so hard to defeat. You wield all weapons single handedly allowing you to equip plasmids in your other hand. This way you can shoot a gun as well as light a foe on fire, personally I was so used to the first one I forgot half the time I could do this. When I finally realized I still found myself not using it as the menu interface to change between plasmids was not as dynamic. This games combat realistically was drastically improved; no longer did you need to keep pulling out the camera during battle to get the best shot, instead you just clicked and it recorded while you were in combat giving you a score for the battle. The remote hacking tool allows you to actually hack cameras, which you could do in the first one but was very tricky as they would almost always detect you before you started the hack. Plus the wrench was changed to a drill which had multiple attack types making it more dynamic. In BioShock I actually used the Wrench all game, so I decided to only use ranged weapons this time round. There are three key combat elements in this game: Weapons, Plasmids (like spells), and tonics (like buffs). The weapons, plasmids, and tonics really allow you to customize your play style. By choosing specific tonics in combination with weapon choose and plasmid choice you can decide if you want to be a melee master, a total hacker, or gunning madman. Plus each weapon, plasmid, and tonic has upgraded versions which make them even more effective and variable. Minerva’s Den:I wasn't sure about Minerva's Den, usually DLC campaigns are just extra levels and lose the elements that make a game great. Minerva's Den was the complete opposite, in fact this DLC story rivals that of the original. There are three levels: Minerva's Den, Operations, and The Thinker. The first two levels are exceptionally large and have many missions/puzzles invovled and the final level is a boss fight. This DLC adds an exceptional amount of depth including a new weapon (Ion Laser) a new Plamid (Gravity Well), two new tonics, and four new enemies. This is an amazing new campaign which offers a brilliant story and fantastic new elements to the BioShock series. Results:BioShock 2 is an amazing game; although, it doesn’t stand up to the story of the original it still provides an amazing play-through. The story itself is relatively well written, and in comparison to non-BioShock games is actually quite brilliant. The combat is fun and rather in-depth with each weapon having three ammo types including the melee tool gives a huge variety to your combat style. You can even customize your tonics and plasmids to enforce the type of gameplay you desire. BioShock really is the FPS for anyone looking for a great story, invigorating combat, epic boss battles, and cool puzzles. I would recommend this game at full price, but if you’re frugal like me and only buy games on sale then wait as anything below its normal price is a steal. Pros:+Fantastic story+Beautiful game environment+Loads of weapons, with different ammo types+Many plasmids (spells) to choose from with upgraded levels+Loads of tonics (passives) to equip which customize your gameplay experience+Three difficulty settings, for all levels of gamers to enjoy.+New dynamic to the BioShock series revealing the inner sanctum of the Big Daddy.+Offers DLC to extend the experience.Cons:-The game allows you to set the difficulty in the menu. I started the game on “Hard” and somehow it dropped to “Medium” at some point. I didn’t notice until a hint popped up about 1/3 the way through when I thought to myself how easy the game was. I bumped it up again to “Hard” and kept a check on it for the rest of the campaign, but this change resulted in my not being able to get the “Against All Odds” achievement. -The game would crash randomly for no reason, I did a verify integrity check but it said the game was fine. In turn I started saving every five minutes so I wouldn’t lose much if it crashed.

												The "best"/least mediocre Bioshock game. I actually kinda liked this one.The story and themes try to copy Bioshock 1 but it kind of ends up being a blander copy in that regard. But screw that! It actually manages to be fun throughout the whole game (unlike Bioshock) and the story isn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ multi-dimension quantum magic pretentious hipster drivel (unlike Infinite). Basically, you're one of the first Big Daddies, and part of Rapture's Splicers have turned, in the 8 years since the first game, into a "Family" led by Female Andrew Ryan with a different philosophy, aka, Sofia Lamb. Your daughter is being controlled by her to be the Ultimate Citizen, and you want to get her back, as a Big Daddy would. There are twice as much endings this time (I didn't check the differences between them because I can't be arsed to), and the difference between these, besides harvesting or rescuing Little SIsters, is that they also depend on certain characters that you save. Or not. Bascially, instead of having 1 choice, you have 4.Gunplay is sort of between Bioshock (mediocre) and Infinite (less mediocre), and though it is slightly more linear than Bioshock at times, it doesn't waste hours of your time with backtracking (hence the shorter gameplay time even though I explored through most nooks and crannies) and the guns are slightly more original than Infinite's: Instead of the WW1 weaponry, you have the Big Daddy's Rivet Gun, a sort of minigun instead of that ♥♥♥♥ Tommy Gun from BS1, a harpoon launcher, a one-handed shotgun and Bioshock1's grenade launcher. You can also dual-wield plasmids, and the upgrades for both plasmids and weaponry are also more original than the 2 other Bioshcok games. Compared to both Ken Levine's Bioshocks, the game also has a lot less full of HP-bloated bullet sponges (though it gets more offensive in this regard towards the last 2 or 3 levels).Bioshock's Little SIster gameplay of harvesting or rescuing Little Sisters after fighting disgustingly HP-bloated enemies turns into adopting or harvesting. If you adopt them (You're a Big Daddy in this game, forgot to mention that) You can reenact the worst level of the first game where you go around letting them harvest ADAM (the magical space-slug chemical that allows you to upgrade your magic powers aka Plasmids) while playing tower defense.You only have to do this once though (for tutorial purposes *sigh*) and in later times you can just send them to the nearest vent and rescue or harvest them. The Big Daddies are not bullet sponges anymore because you have more powerful weaponry (now, there are Brute Splicers for whatever reason, which take up the seat of annoying bullet sponge that charges at you.) To keep a certain amount of dificulty in harvesting/rescuing Little Sisters (even though all difficulty in the Bioshock games is fake because you can just respawn with almost zero cost near where you "died"), at the end of the level, come Big Sisters to get the ADAM you got back. They are sort of a combination of Big Daddies (the charge at you) and Houdini and Spider Splicers (they jump around, and throw fireballs and whatever objects are in the vicinity, at you.) They are not complete bullet sponges, and are fairly fun to fight against.Overall, it's not really a great game, but it sure as hell is better than ♥♥♥♥ing Infinite. And the first game as well.

content:
5, 2015
												TLDR: An enjoyable follow-up to the first game continues the story of Rapture with a new protagonist, a new conflicted (kind of) big boss and more gene splicing action. This time around you have some moral decision making to do, and your actions affect the game’s ending.If you’ve played the first Bioshock game, you’ll remember that in the mid 1900’s the world’s top minds secretly worked together to build the underwater city of Rapture, and created what they thought was the ultimate utopia, free of government and religion. Instead they were ruled by the free market and meritocracy, so everyone makes money based on being good at something. In Bioshock 2, you learn that the pressures of this “perfect world” started to get to the citizens (especially the poor), and a psychiatrist was brought in to help people deal with the stresses of pure competition. Unfortunately, the psychiatrist Sofia Lamb had her own agenda, and saw the opportunity to create a true Utopia in Rapture through the use of Adam. Adam is a genetic material that can be used to create “plasmids” for artificial evolution through gene splicing. It doesn’t just give people super powers though, apparently it can be used to transfer the memories of the users to certain prepared users (Little Sisters). Little Sisters are orphaned girls who have been kidnapped and turned into walking “Adam factories” who can later be harvested for their gooey Adam. The Little Sisters are guarded by Big Daddies, brainwashed people in armored diving gear who are psychically linked to their Little Sisters and guard them from any threat.In Bioshock 2, you play a Big Daddy, though the gameplay is nearly the same as in the first game (where you were a human). It’s still a First Person Shooter and the weapons are mostly the same as well. There’s been a refinement to the plasmid system where you’re basically dual wielding now (plasmid in one hand and gun in the other). In the first game you had to switch between gun and plasmid. A big change is that because you’re a Big Daddy, you do a bunch of mini escort missions where you guard Little Sisters as they gather their Adam. Just like in the first game, you have a huge variety of weapon ammo types and plasmid types to help you survive, though you might notice that the game is more difficult this time around. It seems like you take more damage in Bioshock 2 than in the first game.Pros:+The story is good though it’s a little difficult to figure out what the deal is with Sofia Lamb. How did she turn into such a ♥♥♥♥♥?+The game takes what is good about the first game and adds to it. I kind of liked the hacking mini game in the first game better though. There are more weapon types, more plasmids, and more enemies. The mini bosses in the first game were the Big Daddies, who are back, but now you have the Big Sisters to deal with as well and they’re twice as powerful. +The game has 6 different endings depending on the moral choices you make throughout, but they’re actually very close to each other. I’ve probably only seen 3 of them because I usually play games as a “good person” and had to go out of my way to make evil decisions. Cons:-People have told me that Bioshock 2 is the weakest in the Bioshock series and I can see their point. There really isn’t much more innovation and it’s kind of like a continuation of the first game in terms of technical improvement. Like with Saints Row 4, where people said it was almost a really long DLC for Saints Row 3.-There were some technical issues for me related to graphics. It seems to be a common occurrence based on what I found when googling for solutions. To keep the game from crashing, I had to change the display to Direct X 9.Overall, if you liked the first Bioshock, you’ll probably like Bioshock 2, though maybe not quite as much. The game takes about 10 hours to beat and is more than worth your time.  8.5/10

												I played this game on the 360 when it came out back in 2010. I blazed through it in one night, and revisited the multiplayer once or twice. As a result, I didn't remember much about it. I got into PC gaming a few months ago when I built my first rig, and have really enjoyed it. In the spirit of nostalgia, I bought the Bioshock double pack during an Amazon sale, curious how the games would look on my new machine. So, I embarked on a back-to-back Bioshock playthrough, and I wasn't disappointed. Though the first game is spectacular, and one of my favorites, I found that I enjoyed the sequel far more. I realize this is an unpopular opinion, but bear with me. The mechanics are far more refined and enjoyable compared to the original game. Allowing the player to wield weapons and plasmids simultaneously in particular really spices up the gameplay. All of the weapons are fun to use, notably the trap ammunition. I also felt that the story was much more engaging, and had me more invested than that of the first game. Though the 'WYK' twist is certainly one of the best moments in gaming, it is both the high point, and most memorable story element from the first game. In Bioshock 2, the narrative is woven in a much more consistent manner. Everything you do has purpose, driving you towards your end goal. I didn't get this same feeling in the first game - areas seemed strung together, giving it a more level-based feel.I could extoll the virtues of this game for many more paragraphs, but the only way to truly appreciate it is with first-hand experience. Don't be deterred by those who paint this game as the cash-in middle child of the franchise. Sure, it didn't inject the series with a bunch of new mechanics, but that's not what the development team set out to do. They did, however, deliver a solid game that is worthy to sit on the shelf (or desktop) beside its more well-received siblings.

TL;DRA continuation of a famous sci-fi FPS.+ Fascinating story+ Variety of tools of destruction (Spear Gun FTW!)+ Plasmids+ Atmosphere+ Graphics+ Soundtrack- Gathering ADAM gets old pretty quicklyREVIEWBioshock 2 is the sequel to the innovative sci-fi FPS. It continues the story of the underwater city of Rapture.Several years after the events of the first game, a prototype Big Daddy called Subject Delta is brought back to life in order to find and rescue Eleanor, a Little Sister whom he is bonded with, from the hands of the Rapture's new leader, Sofia Lamb. Sofia is a psychiatrist who believes that only by sacrificing our egos can we make the Earth a good place to live. That is a polar opposite of what Andrew Ryan stood for. Like in the predecessor, there are many voice recordings to be found. Moreover, the gloomy atmosphere of the desolated Rapture combined with the colourful water depths compliments the game perfectly.The gameplay has not changed much – the goal is to complete the given tasks and harvesting or rescuing Little Sisters. There are more enemies and they are a bit more challenging. Feminists have finally been heard and Now there is a female counterpart to the Big Daddies – the Big Mommas Sisters (as if the female leader was not enough...). Moreover, a new mechanic has been added – being a Big Daddy, the player can choose to "adopt" a Little Sister and make her gather ADAM from corpses. The procedure is similar to the good ol' King of the Hill mode – the player has to protect the child while she is harvesting the precious substance. However, it can get old pretty fast.Speaking of additions to the game, there are new weapons and plasmids. For instance, there is a spear gun which I have grown to love (probably more than I should...). In terms of new plasmids, Scout comes to mind. This power lets you deploy a ghost projection that can use plasmids or hack devices. Bioshock 2 supports a variety of playstyles which adds to the replay value. There also is a multiplayer mode.To conclude, Bioshock 2 is a worthy sequel to the original. The combination of the fascinating story, great graphics, and a variety of choices makes it a marvellous title. P.S. 												Let's just start with looking back to first Bioshock which was by the way great gaming experience for me. Splendid idea of underwater city Rapture built with vision of free mind for artist/scientists and other types of creative people that might get limited by their surroundings in world, but not in Rapture.As all previous utopistic societies that went straight into hell - new genetic improvements so called plasmids enhances your physical/psychical abilities in cost of ruining your body and mind (as drugs). But as every addict - you want more... but supplies are limited, so you start thinking about taking some from the others. In Rapture there were two major fractions - people listening to Andrew Ryan (man who built this "paradise") and Frank Fontaine(Ryans rival). After civil war, city was in ruins and people who survived this became weak-minded mutants (splicers) demanding ADAM (genetic material for plasmids).In Bioshock 2 not much really changes from that - except city is more ruined and remaining splicers are uglier and desperate more than ever. Story of Bioshock 2 happens many years after first Bioshock. Power vacuum was filled with new visionary - Sophia Lamb.You play as Big Daddy (subject Delta) whom was taken a little sister (Eleanor) years ago. You wake up revived by vita chamber years after death. And because you are genetically bounded with your little sister, you must find it or you'll die.Your journey begins here...I must say I enjoyed discovering new locations, newly refined plasmids, improved combat system (now you can hold plasmid and gun simultanously) and mainly fact being a big daddy, that giant monster in metal diving suit wearing drill, rivet gun and all...Unlike first Bioshock, this one experiments with multiplayer and I must say it ended half-way to success. It have same atmosphere as Bioshock 1, game modes are fun, gameplay is challenging and entertaining same time, you have a lot of singleplayer elements here (hacking turrets, vending machines etc.), but lack of dedicated servers is biggest problem here and no matter how good gameplay you can offer, absention of dedicated erver bound with horribly coded network code ruins everything.And I don't even mention GFWL and so called "DLCs" with overpowered third gun upgrades, new maps that you could play only if everyone owned that DLC (almost imposible) - I had to struggle with that until I stopped play it from frustration. Finally after some time GFWL closed (hurray for that) Bioshock was moved to Steam platform with all multiplayer expansions for free to all! So I could finally play some nice multiplayer... until people stopped play it so much, well at least I had some quality games before that.It's a must have for every Bioshock 1 fan, but I would recomment it for people who likes interesting FPS shooters with some STORY (not pointing at any bad-story games (lies... lies..))One of the best games I ever played and that is a truth.

   Underwater Fun and Fighting   After completing BioShock 2 and the Minervas Den DLC I think I can now give an unbiased review of both.BioShock 2 was a delightful journey through Rapture, following the events of the 1st in the series. and taking a new twist on the main protaganist and their motivations.There was a steady learning curve, allowing you to build a unique set of skills that include weapons, Plasmids (powers) and perks.  The weapons were varied and the upgrades made a serious change to the basic weapon - the shotgun being suprisingly meaty as it became upgraded.The Plasmids provide enough for whatever playstyle you prefer; ranging from telekenisis to freezing the baddies in their tracks.The addition of the other perks, meant that hacking and use of the drill in more 'intimate' fights, became as important as each other.As always the story develops over several characters, providing a few twists and turns I didn't expect, and it's the 'life' in each charater that serioulsy influences some of the choices that come on offer.  You can be mad, bad and a nasty piece of work, or make alternative choices and be rewarded for your human nature side.I took about 23 hours but did choose to explore and go looking in every nook and cranny (very recommended), but the dying was never so frustrating you wanted to stop.  Some fights lead to several deaths, but a quick swap of tactics and you're out there in the fray again.Minerva's Den is a decent sized DLC (8 hours?) that tells a completly new story, with no mention of the main game.  This allows the writers to put in different characters and make it a "BioSHock 2 Light", with none of the research side of the main game (it's assumed that you know what Houdini Splicer is etc. but the rules are to just kill whatever is shooting at you, so little knowledge of the baddies is really needed).  You will get many hours of fun and get into some real scrapes along the way.Graphics are pretty good on a decent system that can throw the polygons around, the water effects (as you'd expect) are superb, as are the particle and smoke effects.The sound is amazing and really embeds the player into a post-war environment.All in all a sound 9/10.

												Most things from BioShock apply to BioShock 2, so I'll do the rundown on changes.2 Quick discalimers:1-It crashes, a lot, and seemingly for no reason. It doesn't autosave as much as I wanted it to, so save often!2-The scarier moments from BioShock are pretty much gone (make of that what you will), so if you're not a horror fan, you'll probably enjoy this a bit more than BioShock, but it's still pretty bloody.So you're a Big Daddy by the name of 'Subject Delta', but you can still use Plasmids and such, because your a prototype. Your little sister, now a grown-up sister, needs your help after you get ressurected. The story is above average, but overall weaker than BioShock. Similar progression to BioShock as well, semi-linear missions but plenty of exploring for cakes and ammo. We've also got some new characters to go with our new areas too. Another change I like is the visual style. Set 8 years after BioShock, Rapture's leak problem has got a little...bigger...to say the least. The art deco style has been preserved, but there's odd glowing underwater plants and stuff, and the sequences where you get to wander around on the ocean floor are really beautiful. I spent the first 10-ish minutes going 'Whoa, everything's so pretty!'.Gameplay is largely the same, except now we can dual wield Plasmids and Weapons, a much needed improvement, and a full new host of weapons as well. Plasmids are largely the same, but some changes and additions, usual sequel things. I also found I was using a greater variety of weapons and Plasmids than BioShock, where I was often just using Electro-Bolt and the Machine Gun, Gene tonics are more streamlined, so you only have 1 HUGE set of Gene Tonics, which is rather nice as in BioShock, I was often thinking 'gawd, I need more combat tonic slots!'. Hacking isn't total ♥♥♥♥ anymore, just a kinda Quicktime event, but you can still screw up, and you can also hack from a distance, hooray! Enemies are largely the same, two new types of Big Daddy and one new Splicer is all I've seen so far. So pretty solid all round, nothing too different from the original, but some much needed changes.However, BioShock 2 does have a fair swathe of problems. The story isn't as good as before, which is a real weakness. The main antagonist has the most annoying voice ever, and she's always around, but the other characters are fine. As a Big Daddy, when you get to a Little Sister, you have two options: 1-'Adopt' her, take her to a corpse, gather some ADAM as you munch through half your health and Ammo after fighting a butt-ton of Splicers, then do it again, and finally send her to a vent, and I don't think you even get rewards unlike BioShock. Or, 2-Kill her on the spot, 120 ADAM, bam, no fuss, lots of mess, but no uneccesary usage of Health kits.On the note of Health and EVE Hypos: You can only carry 5 of each, but First Aid Kits fully heal you. I found I was often low of health. And it annoys me how you can eat, drink and smoke through your steel diving helmet, unless Subject Delta can absorb nutrients through Osmosis or something.When you are dealing with Little Sisters, there's a chance it can summon a Big Sister, a kind of Mini-Boss. They're kind of annoying, but not a huge ♥♥♥♥ to deal, and you are given proper warning. But please, ONLY spawn one if we're being evil and harvesting them, NOT protecting them with our lives and finally freeing them from their torment.The other two problems are more technical. I found the Audio was very quiet, everything was quite distant most of the time, which is really annoying, especially when sound is so important. The other problem is buttons. Although being able to dual wield is nice, there's a lot of extra keys, and it can get a bit cluttered. Due to too many keys, there's no manual way to reload EVE, which is a real pain in the middle of a fight, so you have to zap yourself to 0, then reload, which is about as fast as the original.But overall, BioShock 2 is still solid. It's kind of like Portal and Portal 2. They're both good games, but BioShock is superior to BioShock 2. The story is less tight than before, and there's some dangling threads here and there. BioShock 2 also has the morality element present, but it's handled a lot better, a bit more grey. And I genuinelly felt sad with the ending I got.

content:
, 2014
												I had written a lengthy, verbose review for this game (before it was inexplicably lost), exploring the narrative genius of Irrational's Bioshock, and the monumental difficulty of crafting a sequel. Such a masterpiece was nearly impossible to follow up, but somehow, in some miraculous, ADAM-infused way, 2K Marin managed it. While the first game explored the downfall of objectivism, and the inner depravity of man, the sequel dives (literally) into the aftermath of the Randian utopia's fall, and the theocratic communism that replaces it. The viewpoints and goals of Bioshock 2's antagonist, Sofia Lamb, is diametrically opposed to those of Andrew Ryan (and Frank Fontaine), which lends this sequel a very different flavour. It remedies Bioshock's failings, however few, and improves upon one of the most versatile and satisfying gameplay systems ever concieved. Bioshock 2 is, truly, worth your time.

er 17, 2015
												I really enjoyed "Bioshock," it really was one of the best games ever made. So naturally, that meant I was looking forward to playing this game. And I was not disappointed. "Bioshock 2" really does manage to keep the fun of it's predecessor, and giving a good story to follow. Though at times, it felt like it was lacking. But I still played through it, and I got a satisfactory enjoyment out of it. I bought this game with "Bioshock" and "Bioshock Infinite", so after completing the first game, I jumped right in to this one.  The story is very heart wrenching, with an interesting theme, and it expands upon it's setting, while still maintaining the spirit of the first game.We return to Rapture in this game, eight years after the first game ended. And it looks worse for the wear. Having played the first game, I really felt some of the awe was gone from wanting to explore. But I still found it fun to see other places in Rapture that weren't in the first game, and I really enjoyed the aesthetics, how much of a novelty this city is. The game uses the same graphics from the first game, but it still keeps the setting looking very nice, and I liked how it incorporated underwater areas, which are very gorgeous to go through. The gameplay is relatively unchanged from the first game. This helps maintain the learning curve the first game had, making it easy for first-time and returning players to get into the game. I still enjoyed using the Plasmids, they're really nice. But I liked how you no longer had to switch from weapons to plasmids, as Subject Delta (the player character) can use both at the same time, which is a definite improvement. I also liked how you no longer needed to divide tonics into categories, giving you one full selection. Like in the first game, you could make Subject Delta your own character with your choice of Plasmids and Tonics to suit your own gameplay style. I tended to focus on hacking more, since I hacked a lot of stuff in this game.But what I really liked was that you were playing as a Big Daddy, allowing you to get a sense of what it's like being one. Whenever you adopt Little Sisters, you can either harvest them or take them with you to gather more ADAM or take them to an air vent and free them. However, the Little Sister defense got really repetitive for me, and more of an annoyance over time, but I really wanted that extra ADAM for more Plasmids and Tonics.The plot wasn't as predictable as I expected, and the game really turned up the morality to make it more meaningful in the long run. It still keeps it straightforward and never overcomplicates it with too much plot, like the first game. It no longer revolves around saving or harvesting Little Sisters. You encounter certain characters who have a connection to Subject Delta, and you get the choice to either kill them or let them live. This really affects how the final act of the game takes place. I also liked Eleanor Lamb, and her connection to Subject Delta in contrast to her connection to Sofia Lamb, giving a great theme of parents going to extreme lengths for their child's welfare. I really hated Sofia and her stupid ideas, and this game suceeds in the same place of making an extremely unlikable antagonist, it makes you keep going.I liked how they changed the hacking minigame, but it's still annoying, as you have to pay very close attention to the needle when it hits the right spot. The enemy variety is unchanged, but with the addition of the Brutes and Big Sisters. Both of them were extremely annoying, even after I got better weapons, plasmids, and ammo. But the Big Sisters, they add more of a risk to saving/harvesting the Little Sisters, and they make you really duck for cover before you fight them, so they do have a bit of a scare factor. And again, USE THE CAMERA! You'll need the research.I overall liked this game. It delivered what it promised, the setting still holds up, the gameplay is still easy to learn, and the plot is still kept pretty simple, and the morality is expanded upon to make it more meaningful. I was disappointed that the game didn't really have much else to offer, but it's still a good time. I intend to play this game again soon.

er 12, 2016
												This game is totally bonkers. Kooky, wacky, and super fun. I went into this one not knowing anything about the Bioshock universe and what a great surprise this turned out to be. Bioshock 2 is unlike anything I was expecting. I dig it.A Howard Huges type industrialist decides it would be a great idea to build New York City deep in the ocean, post World War II. The seafloor city he creates is called Rapture. Over the years everyone who moves in ends up going nuts. The citizens find out a sea slug can be turned into underwater super-meth so they end up addicted as 1950s era zombie drug fiends wearing tuxedos and cocktail dresses. And they join a cult. It's kinda rad. Nobody is keeping up with any building repairs so the whole city is falling apart- and flooding. Rapture's underwater city scape is a nice mix of run down collapsing atomic age buildings and colorful exterior seafloor areas. It's got a nice atmosphere complete with a big band soundtrack and lots of corny fifties kitch that works really well in-game. It reminded me somewhat of Fallout 3 with regard to the black humor and goofy vintage advertisements all over the place. On a side note I'd recommend playing both Bioshock 2 and Fallout 3 back to back. They compliment each other well.In Bioshock 2 you are a weirdo deep sea construction worker with bad breath roaming around in a metal diving suit called 'Big Daddy'. You've got a decade old headache... the underwater bad guys punked you and ripped off your kid. So it's understandable why you are a hater and extra pi$$ed off. You also happen to have some serious telekinetic powers plus a gnarley drill you can gut people with. That's just for starters. Later on you'll pick up a rivet gun, an antique shotgun, a spear gun, and some other odd weapon doo-dads that will put the hurt on hipster brainwashed junkies. Your job is to wreck these jerks and reunite with your little sister. Easy beans, right?The game has a setup whereby you can choose what weapons you want to upgrade incrementally, but there are a limited amount of upgrades available on each level. So choose wisely. Another interesting dynamic is you can literally make the game more difficult on the fly by triggering more boss fights. Attack other Big Daddies as you encounter them to adopt their kid (little sister), or not. If you do whack 'em and snag their little sister you have another choice available to either rescue them or pimp 'em out and harvest the loot. Rescue them enough times and you trigger yet another boss fight. That's pretty cool because you can make the game more painful with more boss fights and get rewarded accordingly or make it easier and not have to brawl as much. It's entirely up to you how you want to play it. The benefit to taking the long hard road and making it tough is you get loot to upgrade your telekinetic powers. One of my favorites turned out to be Hypnotize. Roll into a room with a handful of junkies wandering around loose and Hypnotize them to start an entertaining prison brawl. You can kick back and snag the loot when it's all over.Due to a fair amount of complaints about the Bioshock 2 Remastered version not working well or at all because of a ton of bugs and glitches I decided to play the regular version on my system. The regular version of Bioshock 2 was super stable with no issues to report.

content:
29, 2016
   Underwater Fun and Fighting   After completing BioShock 2 and the Minervas Den DLC I think I can now give an unbiased review of both.BioShock 2 was a delightful journey through Rapture, following the events of the 1st in the series. and taking a new twist on the main protaganist and their motivations.There was a steady learning curve, allowing you to build a unique set of skills that include weapons, Plasmids (powers) and perks.  The weapons were varied and the upgrades made a serious change to the basic weapon - the shotgun being suprisingly meaty as it became upgraded.The Plasmids provide enough for whatever playstyle you prefer; ranging from telekenisis to freezing the baddies in their tracks.The addition of the other perks, meant that hacking and use of the drill in more 'intimate' fights, became as important as each other.As always the story develops over several characters, providing a few twists and turns I didn't expect, and it's the 'life' in each charater that serioulsy influences some of the choices that come on offer.  You can be mad, bad and a nasty piece of work, or make alternative choices and be rewarded for your human nature side.I took about 23 hours but did choose to explore and go looking in every nook and cranny (very recommended), but the dying was never so frustrating you wanted to stop.  Some fights lead to several deaths, but a quick swap of tactics and you're out there in the fray again.Minerva's Den is a decent sized DLC (8 hours?) that tells a completly new story, with no mention of the main game.  This allows the writers to put in different characters and make it a "BioSHock 2 Light", with none of the research side of the main game (it's assumed that you know what Houdini Splicer is etc. but the rules are to just kill whatever is shooting at you, so little knowledge of the baddies is really needed).  You will get many hours of fun and get into some real scrapes along the way.Graphics are pretty good on a decent system that can throw the polygons around, the water effects (as you'd expect) are superb, as are the particle and smoke effects.The sound is amazing and really embeds the player into a post-war environment.All in all a sound 9/10.

content:
er 29, 2015
												Please note:  I played the base game on Hard difficulty.  I have prior experience with first-person shooters and I spent a lot of time checking every nook and cranny for more loot.While its story isn't quite as good as the first Bioshock's, Bioshock 2 more than makes up for it with improved gunplay.  The weapons are only a little different from the original, but they feel a lot better.  Maybe it's because I got the tonic that increases your headshot damage and it made everything die really fast, I don't know.Nothing felt bullet spongey, the only things that had a lot of health were bosses or special enemies that you only see once in a while, and even those can be taken down easily with the right strategy.  The plasmids are all useful and fun, some of the gene tonics are really overpowered a one particular area (not in a way that breaks the game, in a way that's really fun), and the guns all have their own niche in taking down certain enemies.  I used the rivet gun (pistol) the most because it kills most enemies in one headshot (if you have a few upgrades) and the ammunition is plentiful, though I used all of the guns (except for the machine gun) a good deal as well.I found four types bugs/glitches in 20 hours of playing.  Two of them were game-breaking, and the other two were mildly annoying.  The first is constant crashing , if you could call that a bug.  The second is that once, when I started my game, it kept playing the boss fight music even though I had beaten the boss the day before.  Quicksaving and quickloading didn't fix it and neither did restarting my game.  I had to turn off the game's music until I got to the next area, and that's when it stopped.The third is that sometimes your left hand will disappear, and you won't be able to use plasmids.  Restarting the game doesn't fix it either.  The fourth is that sometimes when you take items from shelves, the rest of the items fall through the shelf and onto the floor.  Every once in a while they fall through the world and you won't be able to get them.To fix the crashing, right click Bioshock 2, click properties, click Launch Options, and type -dx9 into the box.  I went from crashing every five minutes to only crashing once in the next ~18 hours, and even then I was alt-tabbing a bunch and had a lot of programs open.The disappearing left hand bug usually happened when I used the Scout plasmid or changed to the Drill Specialist tonic, though some people have had it happen to them when they zoom in.  To fix it, just spam the Zoom/Aim in key, F1, and F2 a bunch.  If you have the drill specialist tonic and this happens, change that tonic to something else at a gene bank, spam the aforementioned keys a bunch, and then change it back.All in all, this is a great game and worth a buy if you played the previous game or like first-person shooters.  I advise that if you haven't played the original Bioshock to play that one first, the world and story will make a lot more sense if you do. P.S.  If you set someone on fire, a Little Sister will remark "Look Daddy, he's dancing!", and that's probably the cutest thing I've ever heard.

content:
er 17, 2015
												I really enjoyed "Bioshock," it really was one of the best games ever made. So naturally, that meant I was looking forward to playing this game. And I was not disappointed. "Bioshock 2" really does manage to keep the fun of it's predecessor, and giving a good story to follow. Though at times, it felt like it was lacking. But I still played through it, and I got a satisfactory enjoyment out of it. I bought this game with "Bioshock" and "Bioshock Infinite", so after completing the first game, I jumped right in to this one.  The story is very heart wrenching, with an interesting theme, and it expands upon it's setting, while still maintaining the spirit of the first game.We return to Rapture in this game, eight years after the first game ended. And it looks worse for the wear. Having played the first game, I really felt some of the awe was gone from wanting to explore. But I still found it fun to see other places in Rapture that weren't in the first game, and I really enjoyed the aesthetics, how much of a novelty this city is. The game uses the same graphics from the first game, but it still keeps the setting looking very nice, and I liked how it incorporated underwater areas, which are very gorgeous to go through. The gameplay is relatively unchanged from the first game. This helps maintain the learning curve the first game had, making it easy for first-time and returning players to get into the game. I still enjoyed using the Plasmids, they're really nice. But I liked how you no longer had to switch from weapons to plasmids, as Subject Delta (the player character) can use both at the same time, which is a definite improvement. I also liked how you no longer needed to divide tonics into categories, giving you one full selection. Like in the first game, you could make Subject Delta your own character with your choice of Plasmids and Tonics to suit your own gameplay style. I tended to focus on hacking more, since I hacked a lot of stuff in this game.But what I really liked was that you were playing as a Big Daddy, allowing you to get a sense of what it's like being one. Whenever you adopt Little Sisters, you can either harvest them or take them with you to gather more ADAM or take them to an air vent and free them. However, the Little Sister defense got really repetitive for me, and more of an annoyance over time, but I really wanted that extra ADAM for more Plasmids and Tonics.The plot wasn't as predictable as I expected, and the game really turned up the morality to make it more meaningful in the long run. It still keeps it straightforward and never overcomplicates it with too much plot, like the first game. It no longer revolves around saving or harvesting Little Sisters. You encounter certain characters who have a connection to Subject Delta, and you get the choice to either kill them or let them live. This really affects how the final act of the game takes place. I also liked Eleanor Lamb, and her connection to Subject Delta in contrast to her connection to Sofia Lamb, giving a great theme of parents going to extreme lengths for their child's welfare. I really hated Sofia and her stupid ideas, and this game suceeds in the same place of making an extremely unlikable antagonist, it makes you keep going.I liked how they changed the hacking minigame, but it's still annoying, as you have to pay very close attention to the needle when it hits the right spot. The enemy variety is unchanged, but with the addition of the Brutes and Big Sisters. Both of them were extremely annoying, even after I got better weapons, plasmids, and ammo. But the Big Sisters, they add more of a risk to saving/harvesting the Little Sisters, and they make you really duck for cover before you fight them, so they do have a bit of a scare factor. And again, USE THE CAMERA! You'll need the research.I overall liked this game. It delivered what it promised, the setting still holds up, the gameplay is still easy to learn, and the plot is still kept pretty simple, and the morality is expanded upon to make it more meaningful. I was disappointed that the game didn't really have much else to offer, but it's still a good time. I intend to play this game again soon.

content:
4, 2014
												Bioshock 2 is an older game now (nearly 4 years!) and has been reviewed many times; I'll repeat one thing that was common to a lot of those: If you liked Bioshock, you'll like Bioshock 2.  It doesn't have _quite_ as much impact as the former, largely due to the change of protagonist.  As Jack, even spliced up, you felt small.  Human.  Vulnerable.  There was a mile of freezing seawater between you and escape, and the lunatics had free run of the asylum... and drowning was something you would have no problem doing.  As Subject Delta (or, in Minerva's Den, Subject Sigma), you feel like a Big Daddy.  A little ponderous, but armoured, tough, and more than capable of beating a few splicers to death.The story isn't quite as brilliant either - in the first game, Rapture was new (to you), and everything was exploration of Andrew Ryan's ruined dream.  Well, in 2, Rapture is just as pretty, just as fascinating... but not quite as new.  There's a certain sense of familiarity for those who've played through the first game and spent quite a few hours in the slowly decaying city.  It's worth noting that as with the first game, the art assets for Bioshock 2 are stunning.  Post-apocalyptic art deco and water effects make for a feast for the eyes.Some of the new Plasmids (plus the ability to use guns and plasmids at the same time) make for some real fun, mechanically, and even if you're feeling like a nice, tough Big Daddy, the Splicers haven't been sitting still either.  There are some real challenges at the higher difficulty levels.Overall, if you don't have it, but have played Bioshock, get this game, and play it.  If you don't have it, and _haven't_ played Bioshock, get Bioshock.  Then get this game and play it. :)

content:
y 5, 2014
												Bioshock 2 is a massive step up from the first game. The graphics have been improved and look more realistic and less like clay. The combat and weapons are refined and are much better. They took most of the problems from the first one and fixed them. For starters, you finally have a melee weapon that does damage! The wrench in BS1 was useless, but in BS2, you have a powerful drill, and you can also use your other weapons to melee. Another is that they fixed the lack of ammunition. In BS1, I barely scraped by the skin of my teeth. Ammo was insanely hard to find, and when you did find it, it indicated a boss fight or massive fight scene up ahead. But one problem I have is that the enemies do so much more damage to you. In BS2, you play as an old Big Daddy. Yet, it seems like your armour is useless as the enemies pound through it. By far, this is the best Bioshock game to date, far surpassing Infinite. It may follow a repetitive gameplay style, but it is so addictive. The voice acting is incredibly good, and you will find yourself attached to characters like Sinclair who guide you to stopping Lamb. It's both the same, and far different than Bioshock 1.But one of the main things I love about this game is how they changed the hacking mechanics. Originally, to hack something, you had to click on tiles and drag pipes and connect them so water flows from the input to the output. This was incredibly tedious, and I hated it so much that I tryed to avoid hacking as much as possible (except when I needed ammo). I was overjoyed to see that in BS2, they added a more easier hacking system. Just press the arrow when it's over a green or blue square. If you miss, you get electrocuted or it summons a security alarm which spawns the annoying little helibots.But the best improvement is gathering Adam. In BS1, to get Adam, you have to find a Little Sister. To get to a Little Sister, you have to go through her Big Daddy defender. Once you did that, you could either harvest or rescue her. But in BS2, there is a third option. Instead, you can 'adopt' her, she sits on your shoulder until you find a suitable Adam source. While she gathers it, you defend her from the Splicers while the protaganists mock you.  I love how they improved the relationship between Little Sister and Big Daddy, and now you can become a part of that. Bioshock 2 is hands down the best Bioshock experience. Its as dark as its predecessor, but has much better game mechanics and graphical improvements. The characters, from Sinclair to Lamb are engaging and really interesting people. The worlds are bigger and beautiful than Bioshock 1. Fantastic sequel. Improved mechanics, awesome story and graphics.8/10

												The ultimate anal-drilling-simulation leaves a bit of an aftertaste of ♥♥♥♥ in the players mouth, which might source from the fact that gameplay from the first game remains virtually unchanged, or that at heart, you drill splicers bumholes until they explode or you spend hours drilling a big daddy until he anticlimatically doesn't explode.Bioshock 2 has great level design and an above average story (which contains more plotholes than you can create bumdrilling splicers in the entire game) and continues the atmosphere of the first game in most aspects. If you are really into diving for  30 seconds max in between shootouts, you might really like this game too. Although it might not seem that way, the game has really good pacing and never have I felt bored playing the game, although it can be tiring to fight a big sister with as much health as a ♥♥♥♥ing level 90 tank in WoW. Most of that comes from the weaponry; as I previously mentioned, you get to shove your typical Big-Daddy-Drill into any splicers bumhole, and there are a couple really powerfully handled, awesome weapons to be found and upgraded. You feel actuallystrong in the game, not just like some flexed up Bodybuilder with double the ♥♥♥♥ that his mother possessed. But just like that particular roid-rage Arnold-Cutout, Bioshock 2 has one great weakness: The Glory of his predecessor. You can't top Arnold. He is just too glorious.Would I recommend? Yes.Would I say "Iss best Bioshock GG"? No.Would I try out the rotating Fist position? Possibly.8/10 would drillfist again

er 13, 2014
												After playing the first two games in the BioShock series and starting the third, I can honestly say I like 2 more. Gameplay and Customization: BioShock 2 managed to fix the clunkiness of its predecessor when it comes to shooting. It allows iron sights, which is awesome, and quick plasmid usage. The way this works it you have a weapon on your main hand and plasmid on your off hand at the same time. The variety of plasmids is also cool. The customization of BioShock games never cease to amaze me. Whether you want to be big badass Delta with a drill and offensive plasmids, or take a more subtle approach with the spear gun and stealthy plasmids, Bioshock 2 can provide such an experience. Hacking and Research: This game decided to simplify hacking. Instead of having to play a puzzle minigame like in BioShock, you now need to land the hack needle on green or blue zones, green successfuly completeing hack while blue doing the same plus giving a free item. The Research system was overhauled. Instead of taking pictures of the target to gain research, now you have to video tape them. To get the best possible research, one must kill the target using a mixture of weapons, plasmids, npcs or security bots. Story and Atmosphere:	 I don't understand why people don't like the story of BioShock 2. Though it doesnt follow Jacks life, which was clearly ended at the end of BioShock, its still pretty interesting.  The adventure of Delta and Sinclair on their way to save Eleanor was a great idea. They made sure to make you sad when you had to put down Sinclair. Also the endings are either sad of bad, there is no real happy one.  BioShock 2 does a great job in keeping the experience atmospheric, just like in the first game. Overall:	 This game is better than the first one. If you like any of the above features, its a must have. 10/10 would take fall damage to see Delta make a mini earthquake.

content:
, 2014
												This game, though not as atmopsheric as the first game is nonetheless a wonderful experience to behold. The combat system, if somewhat imbalanced the first round is more exciting here. You get a whole host of new weapons to wield and with the camera research system, it also awards you for being creative enough to combine multiple ways to destroy your enemies. The hacking system has also been revamped and greatly improved, no longer must you figure out how to twist and place tubes but instead try to hack system whilst dodging enemy fire makes for a exciting experience. The choice system is also more nuanced and rather than ending with Very Good vs Very Bad, it takes into account how your actions with non-Little Sister characters would affect you (greatly missing from the first game).The story expands the Rapture universe, if the first game is somewhat large-than-life when it comes to your characters, Bioshock 2 helps makes them more human. It also smartly avoids to try and emulate the first twist that was the first game and made the storyline simple, you're a Big Daddy and now you must rescue your Little Sister. Rather than just keeping it that simple, it also introduces Ryan's counterpart with Sofia Lamb, who is an antagonist who took the extreme version of Ryan's much hated Altruism to its logical point (and this works better here than Bioshock Infinite's extremism comparisons but I digress).One of the few cons, however is that the creepy atmosphere of the first game is quite missing. Even though you're exploring the more downtrodden areas of Rapture, I find it more bright and more combat focused than the beginning. And the PC version had audio bugs and glitches that seriously undermines the more dramatic aspects of the game. Imagine you're playing an area where you're besieged by Splicers but the audio decides to fritz up and you fight in total silence. I would also like to comment on how this game crashes at odd moments - if you're the sort to forget to save once in a while, say goodbye to your progress and you will be forced to replay the level from the beginning. The Multiplayer aspect is a hit and miss. It would have been fun but due to a lack of servers, you'd forced to either wait for some time for everyone to play (and even then it's rare for one to be able to play anything besides Civil War). Forget about a balance firefight as well, since this game loves to match the newbies with veterans and it's not uncommon to pitch a group pf low leveled players against more experienced ones and watch as a team gets slaughtered in the process. But to be able to see the areas you could only explore in Bioshock return here was amazing, even if you could only explore it solo. I would still recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed Bioshock but wanted some improvements with certain game mechanics. All in all, this game is a worthy addition to the Bioshock series. 4/5
